content:
er 24, 2016
A uniquely compelling game with an intricate storyline, vast amounts of dialogue and interesting technical presentation.This review originally from May 2009.Deus Ex is foremost a unique game in its field. It is really quite unlike any other game I have ever played. It shares territory with titles such as Half-Life and Tomb Raider, but also takes inspiration from some role-playing games as well. It seems to have carved out or invented its personal little niche in the game market, by mixing two normally contrasting game essentials. It manages to successfully combine puzzle, shooting and RPG elements to create a really exceptional atmosphere. While it may have several middling faults which will occasionally make you cringe, it is mostly an extremely fun and thought-provoking game, inspired by both modern conspiracy theories and philosophy.The storyline is based in the near future, and revolves around nano-augmented (basically this just means technologically enhanced) Agent J. C. Denton, who works for the United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition (UNATCO), based out of Liberty Island, New York. As is normal, the world of the future is not a safe place to be, and UNATCO must protect the citizens of the Earth from various terrorist plots and evil denizens. Primarily in the first mission of the game, you must regain control of the Statue of Liberty and Liberty Island, which has been seized by an organisation known as the NSF (National Secessionist Forces). The plot is far to complex to go into detail, and it would also spoil the game, but save to say that the basic premise is that Denton must work to solve problems relating to deadly viruses (which has the lovely sounding name Grey Death), corrupt governments and world domination attempts. The plot is really the best aspect of Deus Ex, as without it, it would not have anywhere near the same novelty value. The game is also extremely long, taking often upwards of twenty hours to complete, and if you were to go hunting for all the many hidden locations, objects and side-quests it will take much longer. Luckily, there are only a few dull moments during this, as you will be visiting New York, Hong Kong and Paris on the globe-hopping crusade. It can however become slightly annoying when you must retrace your steps several times in order to return to previous locations in each city. During this epic journey Denton talks to literally dozens and dozens of other characters, all of whom have a great array of responses, and can be conversed with many times. However, this leads me to probably one of the largest faults of Deus Ex: the character voices.Although every character talks a great deal, and the scripts themselves are very good and involving, the voice acting is frankly rather below standard. Absolutely no characters (with the possible exception of arch villain Bob Page) seem to have any genuine emotions in their voices at all, and instead inhabit a world where emotions have seemingly been destroyed, or at least mainly forgotten about. Denton and his brother Paul both speak like they have walked out of the Terminator films as reincarnations of Arnold Schwarzenegger. Even when people are hurt, they shout or scream only in a vaguely half-hearted manner. Listening to all of these emotionless and mainly blunt conversations can sometimes get a bit tiresome; although you will often be too engrossed in the subjects they are discussing to notice this. On top of this, mainly the musical score is also rather dull, and mostly sounds very similar and unremarkable (though it will inevitably slowly grow on you anyway), apart from the classic main title theme. However, general sound effects and ambient sounds are quite good.Thankfully, gameplay itself is consistently solid throughout. It is theoretically possible to get through the entire game without killing anyone (save from one or two characters who must be incapacitated), as you are given a wide range of both lethal and non-lethal weapons with which to take on enemies. However this can get extremely difficult (as you will be frequently running out of non-lethal ammunition) and furthermore, you are given no incentive to do so (apart from the honour). It is much easier (and often all the more fun) to go in with all guns blazing, although this may not always be the best way to handle a given situation. Shooting and targeting is relatively easy, although it can be tricky earlier in the game when skill levels are lower. Graphically, the game isn't much to look at today, but that just gives it the much sought after "classic" feel.A nice touch is to give Denton the various abilities to learn skills such as lock-picking, hacking computers, swimming and making aiming easier, through the reward of skill points, which are earned by achieving certain goals or fully exploring the different maps. This can make your own version of Denton able to complete certain tasks much easier. At first, this system seems overcomplicated, and to be frank it often is leading to an RPG-ish feel, and could have probably been implemented more simply, though the scheme is easily workable. The gameplay also has several nice problem-solving virtues, and situations can be resolved through a number of ways. The game makes use of a detailed inventory menu, from which you can see objects picked up, check health and review known information and objectives. Also, you handling of situations will influence other characters views and opinions of you, subtly changing the storyline. Due to this, it is very unlikely you will ever replay exactly the same story.Deus Ex is simply different from anything else, and stands out from the crowd on its own plinth. It is a welcome change from the more stereotypical action-adventure, and blends many different elements almost seamlessly together. Although it does have some minor faults, I still highly recommend it to anyone, as everyone should be able to overlook the mediocre voice acting and still thoroughly enjoy this game, in all its "cyberpunk" glory. In retrospect, Deus Ex has to be looked upon as a worthy contender in any “Greatest Games” list. The true value lies in the morality, philosophy and conspiracy themes the story focuses upon, which help to stimulate both the mind and psyche.

content:
ry 3, 2015
												Deus Ex 10 / 10 (2001)Play as Secret Agent Denton to serve and defend your Country.... A 3D First Person Adventure. The Story is Complex; discover plans within plans and be prepared to make choices that have a drastic impact on the game and the finale(s). 100% Enjoyable. Develop your Character's Skills with Nanobot upgrades, there are multiple paths that will allow you to play Your prefered Strategy (Negotiate VS Sneak VS Speed VS FullMetaljacket). This was one of the first real Sandbox games, so many paths at every point .... so many options.I originally played this on a 17" Mac in 2001. I locked myself in the Room after the first 30 minutes and marathoned the game in 2 days. I was hooked. Since then I have replayed DeusEx many times.... including when it came out on Steam (2007). It has lost none of the Magic. This game was My Favorite Game of All Time (2001 - 2012) because the story was so rich but did not get in the way; the player is Free to discover as much or as little of the story as necessary; One of the greatest games of all time....The Story will captivate you. The Graphics are dated but not distracting. The Audio is quite engaging, and a number of the compositions are simply outstanding (esp. in Paris and in Hong Kong). The Remix of 'Siren Synapse' (The Hong Kong Theme) by the OST Composer himself Alexander Brandon is available on OCRemix.org and is a real gem.... get it on this page under the 'download' tab near the top:http://ocremix.org/remix/OCR01914Interview with Alexander Brandonhttp://ocremix.org/info/Composer_Interview:_Alexander_BrandonAfterthoughts: This is not Quake or some other FPS....

number of helpful: 11 of 12 people (92%) found this review helpful
content:
er 23, 2016
												A game with a great story that has a lot of crazy plot twists and many different maps ranging from New York to Hong Kong and Paris, all made extremely well to cater to both stealthy and guns-blazing gameplay. A traditional RPG in the sense that you are able to make J.C Denton exactly how you want him to be, with many different things that you can upgrade, ranging from combat abilities like improving his aim with rifles or pistols, and non-combat abilities like lockpicking and hacking. You can acquire the points needed through completing the current map, many different side quests that can be found in that area and also finding secret locations. The combat in the game can be seen as dated by lots of people and they are not wrong, but when you take into account that it has to be how it is due to it being an RPG, you will learn to forgive it. How the combat abilities work is that you will need to aim your crosshair on the enemy and it will slowly become smaller, which gradually improves the accuracy of your shot. So, if you do not train in the pistol skill, it's going to be very inaccurate and slow to become accurate and will lead to boring tedious gameplay, so I personally recommend upgrading your pistol skill to Trained right at the beginning of the game.There is lots of great albeit corny dialogue throughout the game with all the amazing characters in it. The only negatives for this game is that it is relatively uneasy to get into due to the first map being extremely large and it's quite easy to get lost. Also, some of the dialogue in the game are very low quality, not in the sense that the writing is bad because it's a game from the year 2000, but some of the mics that the voice actors used were very poor quality. Some areas like Hong Kong and Paris have characters with hard to understand accents, and this is most likely on purpose as English would not be their primary language, and personally I loved this.If running on a modern system, I recommend getting some things that allow for higher resolutions and increased FOV, there is a great guide on Steam which helped me a lot in quickly setting it up. In my opinion, don't use the HD character models.


Deus Ex Setup Guide for modern systems 
A Guide for Deus Ex: Game of the Year Edition
By: Saleck

			This guide will help you get Deus Ex running with the  New Vision Mod  which will greatly enhance your Deus Ex experience, the Deus EXE udated Executable and Direct3D10 drivers to get the game running optimally.

												So this, the original Deus Ex is a game that defies logic. 16 years after inital release this game it remains the only game that truly follows through on the promise that any playstyle can complete the game. the ability to simply sneak past an enemy or snipe it from across the map, or even run around with a lazer sword swinging away at anything that moves. content:
er 13, 2012
												Deus Ex is a game that most of you should know already. It is a game that revolutionized the FPS genre as the original "Thinking Man's Shooter". It was groundbreaking in every single aspect, from the open-ended gameplay to the storytelling to the RPG elements it borrowed.Basically, Deus Ex is an FPS with some RPG elements added on to give your character a better sense of progression. You start off as just another agent but as you improve your skills and acquire new implants you become a truly unstoppable force.The maps are huge and sprawling with tons of enemies and civilians and there is never just one way of going about accomplishing your objectives. Everywhere is littered with secret tunnels, hidden stashes, locked doors, automated defenses and patrolling sentries. Although the storyline isn't quite open enough to say that every game plays differently you can safely say that each map has hundreds of different ways to complete it.The storyline will from the start seem like a classic cops vs. terrorists but as you progress through the game you will find that nothing what it seems and nobody is who they pretend to be. You will find that your actions have real tangible gameplay consequences as you decide who should die and who should live and there are many surprises waiting for you down the line.It's not a game that holds your hand and tells you who to kill and who to spare, more often than not a first time player will allow his enemies to live never realizing that there are real consequences and rewards to putting a gun to their head and ending their existence right there. Similarly there are those who can be spared or saved from death that will come back to help you or haunt you later in the game. This is all something you have to figure out for yourself as you play through the game and I wouldn't want to spoil it for you.Although the graphics have aged quite a bit since it's release the availability of high-resolution texture packs and other fan-made graphical enhancements means it's playable even in this day and age.Deus Ex is perhaps one of the greatest games ever released for PC and, in my humble opinion, the greatest shooter ever released. It's only real competition being from the System Shock games.Truly a masterpiece of gaming and hopefully one day we will see a proper sequel.

content:
19, 2016
												The original Deus Ex has made its way into my all-time favourites since my very first time playing it about three years ago, and it is unfortunate that I did not experience this masterpiece when it came out. Just over two months ago, I finished replaying it, and those were amazing two-odd weeks ploughing through its almost perfect campaign.This is the ultimate epitome of a first-person role-playing game. Even its very few flaws do not result in any considerable frustration, and the fluidity in gameplay and mechanics outbalance the blemishes, thanks to its excellent insertion of the augmentation system and its relevance to mission progression, or its meticulously designed maps, or its well-balanced and concise skill chart. Stealth would need a little improvement in terms of AI response and timing of critical moments (e.g. the player finds situations in which, after being flat-out spotted, the only urgency is to hide behind a crate so that the sin is forgiven), and it must be said that this is the game’s most apparent problem. In sum, the challenge that the stealth element poses is greatly reduced by the enemy’s poor response and follow-up actions to spotting. Another problem is the shallow issue of graphics and general animation. Naturally, this is a minor aspect to worry about, but it could be argued that textures, as well as said animations, are not en par with games from the same period, such as the posterior Return to Castle Wolfenstein, or even the preceding System Shock 2; both more visually appealing than Deus Ex.It could be argued that story, writing and player’s choice are the pillars that hold the game up there on the eRPG Olympus. The main premise encompasses themes such as global conspiracy, scientific/pharmaceutical agendas, corporate domination of geopolitics, and the confines of biological manipulation. The approach to such themes demonstrates the maturity and profound research done by main writer Sheldon Pacotti, and the ideological directions that the game can take will depend solely on the player, without any biases ultimately affecting the general mood. Main missions are no-nonsense tasks that are as intimately related to the plotline as a story-driven gaming narrative can get, and the side missions are an additional flavour to the lore that periodically unravels with each book or data vault accessed. Everything works in perfect unison. The long and versatile campaign can be played several times and still not be exhausted from all the plot possibilities that arise should the player simply pick a different choice when dealing with a major objective. The choices shall always be there, whether the headway involves breaching into a building to reach a quest target’s whereabouts, or choosing the fate of the populace from a destitute area portrayed in a grim future. Additionally, the story carries convincing alternate chronicles for the fictional geopolitical scenario that it proposes: the protagonist J. C. Denton travels to multiple locations in different real-world countries and, either through news segments found on papers casually lying about or through dialogue, is able to make sense of the plot and the dystopian intricacies that it articulates. In fact, every piece of plot-related data is cleverly placed and communicated, and even the interpolations are executed meticulously and with later lore to back it up as the player advances through the missions. The several twists in the narrative never wane, precisely because every bit of adversity is accounted for during gameplay and is there to integrate the political dilemma posed by the storyline.Remarkably orchestrated, Deus Ex excels at virtually every aspect of gaming development, which paved the way for the title to become such a successful franchise afterwards. Incorporation of several gameplay dynamics may be its most notable quality – quite a novelty for a late-90s/early-2000s game, and a virtue that it shares with the likes of the aforementioned System Shock 2, for instance –, even though story and writing may be its greatest one *for an RPG*. In terms of audio production, besides some decent voice acting, the beautiful soundtrack conveys the game’s cyberpunk aesthetics, and the synth-based music is an aural delight composed by Unreal genius Alexander Brandon and Michiel van den Bos, among others. Deus Ex is a genuine gem of its time and onwards; a complete package for those who crave for a mature action-RPG experience and/or for those who want a taste of high-quality sci-fi in a videogame.

content:
ber 9, 2016
Soon you will have your God, and you will make it with your own hands.Often considered the greatest game of all time, I came into the original Deus Ex with high expectations. I played entirely unmodded, wanting to see what the game was like all those years ago. GameplayProbably the most important factor in the enjoyment of a game is gameplay, and Deus Ex delivers in this department. It does take some time to adjust to the somewhat clunky controls and mechanics of the game, but when it all finally clicks for you after some experimenting, you feel immensely rewarded. All it takes is to find a style of play you really enjoy, and there are many different styles. For example, the first mission provides you with an immediate choice of weapons: Rifle, Crossbow or GEP Gun. Then you are let loose to blast terrorists or sneak around, or any mix of the two. So many different choices in every level, it would take me a very long time to describe it here. StoryI don't want to spoil anything, because the story is one of the best I've experienced in gaming. But here is the basic premise: You are the newest agent in anti-terrorist organization UNATCO and are sent to stop a group of terrorists called the NSF from stealing a cure to a virus... The story unfolds from there...Graphics, Atmosphere and SoundThe graphics are quite dated but still functional. There should be no real issues here; gameplay and story is what matters. The main issue is facial animation for me, and I did get some texture clipping, but mods and other things likely fix this. The atmosphere is great, I felt as though I was actually there. I don't, again, want to spoil anything; it's best if you experience it for yourself. The soundtrack is truly excellent; a techno-beat to most of the music, and a little bit of jazz sprinkled in here and there; brilliant stuff. I listen to it outside of the game it's that excellent. ConclusionIf you have never played Deus Ex, then what are you waiting for? At least say you gave it a fair go, and you will have been able to experience what was once the height of gaming, and now is relegated to perhaps a lesser position, but is still truly excellent. jmcone's personal rating: Highly Recommended

content:
r 29, 2015
Before rambling, I would like to give a special thanks to Brother Tasty and my actual brother, TableTerrorsMatt, for proof-reading this review. Deus Ex is a stealth action game created by Ion Storm in the year 2000. Now this legendary entry in the gaming industry is considered one of the most innovative of all time to many, included in its theme of stealth, roleplaying, choice, action, exploration, and many other labels, as its popularity has transcended since its creation. In Deus Ex, you play as protagonist JC Denton, an operative for UNATCO who’s primary focus is to thwart a terrorist organization, NSF’s, tactics, such as the theft of a chemical weapon known as Ambrosia. The player given primary and optional objectives during the briefing for each mission, and then are allowed free reign to complete said objectives in, pretty much, any way they wish.Here are a few items that I found of interest in Deus Ex:Roleplaying - As protagonist JC Denton, players traverse various stages with given objectives while gaining experience points to enhance aspects of their character’s statistics. The upgrade system is impeccable, and allows the player to proceed in situations in nearly any way possible, which allows for multiple forms of play and progression. Another element of great importance is how choices-both in and out of dialogues-affect an abundance of things within the game. For example, your starting equipment choices and statistics will influence how you manipulate the world and its peoples, allowing you to uncover a multitude of secrets. Simple actions such as going to the ladies’ restroom to check for loot may prompt simple dialogue changes, hence why Director Joseph Manderly, the protagonist’s boss, scorned me for doing so. A touch of realism is portrayed in Deus Ex as well since getting paid actually feels like getting paid. For example, Director Manderly will explain your monetary and experience gains after each mission within a conversational flow, which accentuates a seamless transition between operations and downtime.Stealth System - It is difficult to entirely describe the sensation that is this title’s stealth gameplay presents. Character augments, statistical upgrades, and player skill all contribute to the experience, yet this game seemingly knows how to also look past these and simply demonstrate a stealth ‘feel’ in comparison to relying on only the said features. Like nearly every other game created in the genre, the player can maneuver while hidden through territories by utilizing the crouch command-activated with the Control key-and by passing silently in the shadows, preferring muffled or melee eliminations over brutal assault. Several useable items such as the stun rod and tranquilizer rounds for the crossbow emphasize the purpose of stealth, but are not so overpowered that it makes the approach simple; player timing and cunning are key to success while dodging enemy forces in Deus Ex.Player and Non-Player Dialogue - As described previously, many of the actions that JC Denton can perform may be mentioned by non-player characters throughout the game; some of these exchanges can occur randomly-such as in the incident mentioned within the spoiler text-, but mostly appear within conversation with others. There is also a great dialogue selection when speaking with civilians or UNATCO personnel ranging from calm and inquisitive to brash threatening.Level Design - Though similar themes may be present through individual missions, each level retains its own unique feel and layout that abstains from any two levels being blindly alike. Deus Ex utilizes a multiple-layer design in many of its missions, with street-, basement-, and roof-accessible venues that contribute to the open-ended gameplay; this may not seem like a huge feature, but with so many stealth action games forcing players to endure ‘straight’ level mechanics while claiming its style to be open-world, this ideal is magnificent. Strewn throughout each level are also intricately-placed traps and alarms that Gary Gygax himself would be proud of.TL:DR - Deus Ex is undoubtedly a legend in the gaming world, and continues to shine in its current age. This title near-flawlessly executes a stealth gameplay experience that all fanatics of the genre must play. There is so much more I would like to say about Deus Ex but nothing anyone could say can truly bring justice to how innovative this game was and still is. I highly recommend this title to individuals who enjoy stealth action, roleplaying, and cyberpunk themes. Thanks for reading.Do you enjoy these reviews? Please visit my Curator Page at  Spearpoint Reviews	.

Choice and Consequence.Even in recent times, no other game comes close to the feeling of choice and consequence that Deus Ex offers.Along with atmosphere and quality of writing, it's one of the game's most obvious strengths. They are both factors that persist throughout the entire game allowing players to forge their own J.C Denton. At a time when players had not seen this marriage of complex storytelling but in a 3d world, Deus Ex managers to offer up an incredibly rich and adult story while pulling it off effortlessly. Huge props to the writers(s)Unfortunately time has not been kind to the gameplay and presentation of Deus Ex. The game was not a stunner on release, and the gameplay will definitely seem antiquated to most people. But it's not bad by any means, it just lacks a lot of niceties that modern games offer.Do yourself the favour. It's consistently named the best PC game of all time for a reason...

er 1, 2014
												The ambience, the environment itself, the sensations I felt when I picked it up for the first time were...inefable. Okay this game is so great because some guys from Looking Glass (the dev team behind SS2, that is System Shock 2) decided to make another great game.It is pretty similar to SS2 in a variety of ways:-inventory-Role-Playing-Game features are almost alike-weapons are almost alike tooThere is something more:-talking with other people will help you get through a lot of troubles-there is some simple Stealth mechanic which makes the game more interesting-non-linearity makes replaybility feasible-deep reasonings around philosophical concepts (not too much I assure you and they are not unnecessarily mind-bogglingly complicated as Hegel)This game talks about how humans modified their bodies to become more powerful through cyber implants. This shifted human potential limitessly. You are the newest model: a genetic enhanced human being. Someone is hiding something, but for the moment you are safe. Watch your back Agent, for lots of issues lie up ahead.There is the DeusEx Editor if you wish to spend some time building your own levels.In short:I recommend this game because it is a must have in the FPS-RPG hybrid genres. I consider this game as the indirect offspring of SS2 and because it is a lot more deep than most games nowadays, I want you to consider this tiny review with a great deal of care.Thanks for reading.

content:
2, 2014
												Let me start off by saying that I am not writing this as if I'm halfway into the game or I've only completed the first mission and collectively soiled myself in pure excitement and leftover tacos. No, I have just finished the game not more than 10 minutes ago, and managed to grab all 3 endings in the process. I will tell you right now, although games like Oblivion and Portal cloud my top 5 favorite games with the ham fisted strength of nostalgia, this game is one of the greatest games I have ever experienced. The stealth is near-superb, with the only hiccups being that bodies will go undetected and JC will be chewed out for killing, even though everyone was rendered unconscious. I played through the game utilizing only the stealth crossbow, taser, and police baton in a fruitful effort of not killing anyone, but the beauty is that you can play through however you want. Depending on how you allocate your skills, you can speed through maps toting a nuclear death launcher or a small machine gun, paving the way with bullets. You can be cautious and invest in disabling security, then sneakily headshotting enemy troopers. Or you can be like me, and be the ghost that is never seen. All of the above only focuses on the gameplay aspect. The story? Fantastic. It has the right amount of plot deviations and well versed story telling that surrounds itself in conspiracy. The graphics? They are subpar, but for the year 2000, not too bad. The soundtrack? While it is very 2000-centric in nature, it still holds up very well and fits the mood of the area. It will leave your ears wanting more and more.So, do I recommend this game? Yes. Yes, very much so. No matter what your playstyle is, the game will fit it like a glove. Don't hesitate to purchase.

content:
31
												Members of the Trilateral Commission have gone on to become Presidential candidates and there is a conspiracy among these well connected elites to use the powers of the UN to bring about a global world order that begins with a continuation of a historical process that has been occuring since the 1920's whereby the wealth gap increases until we begin sanctioning off the lower classes and killing them off in a modern form of Eugenics where only the wealthy and elite survive.JC Denton: "Do you have a single fact to back that up?"It was at that moment that I loved JC. This is what I like about JC: he's realistic. I'm tired of dimwitted protagonists that act shocked at twists we all saw coming, or act like teenage anime protagonists that believe in the power of friendship. JC is real. Albeit a little...odd. I think they were aiming for "Robo-cop" with him, which would explain his frank, albeit odd, manner of speaking. Such as when someone asks if their new partner is going to be the type to wear gaudy glasses, to which he reponds, "my vision is augmented". It's pretty humorous how matter-of-fact he is, but entertaining as well. I like it.In case you haven't figured it out, Deus Ex is a video game taking place in an alternate future where all the conspiracy theories Alex Jones espouses are actually true. You're Jesus Christ Denton, an augmented agent of UNATCO, a UN style organization that attempts to maintain the peace of the world, a world gripped by a dystopian future whereby a "Gray Death" illness is causing turmoil among the lower classes as the pandemic kills off people and the rations of cures seem to only go to the upper class. The game has you going out on missions in large maps with primary objectives and secondary objectives you get right away or by talking to locals. The maps are large because the levels are meant to be tackled in various ways, such as through grates or hacking. You're meant to explore levels and find a way to accomplish your goal, which is why this game has meme status as a title meant to be replayed over and over for years on end. It's sort of amazing that even to this day this level of openness in accomplishing objectives still feels fairly new. And it's not as if Deus Ex is some MONOLITH title where you can do 900 different things to complete an objective, but the fact that more games haven't caught on is sort of surprising. It's not as if the game has a divergent plot: the plot still moves down a linear path, so you can't say that linear storytelling is impossible if you have options in gameplay.I will say that the game's shooting mechanics leave a lot to be desired. The game's combat handles oddly; it's not bad or anything, it's just not the best shooter. I talked to someone about this and they told me its becase Deus Ex isn't a shooter...and with all the options in how to tackle objectives...I can sort of see their point. Or rather, it doesn't HAVE to be primarily a shooter, which is to its benefit as its a below average shooter. The game is like this partially because there are upgrades to weapons for accuracy and reload times, and you can upgrade proficiency in these weapons through your skill tree. My only issue with it is that it doesn't feel like you're ADDING to your proficiency but rather placing BACK what the developers took AWAY. There's a definition between addition to the original and placing back what was originally there; it's like actual DLC and merely unlocking what's on the disc. The game becomes a better shooter when you upgrade, but you'll have to really go far into the game for taht to happen.Also, unlike MGS where gunfire and shots alert the facility and everyone takes note, in this game an enemy firing his gun at you and getting killed won't necessarily alert his allies in the facility. It's not really a large issue, but it leads to a sense that the enemy alertness and ai isn't fantastic as you get away with making more noise than you really should be able to. You can have a loud firefight with a shotgun and after taking out two people, go back to stealthing as if nothing happened, so long as you take out the people in the immediate vicinity. It becomes apparent that this isn't MGS levels of tightness in stealthing. Despite that, move over Half Life why wasn't this game of the decade for 2000-2010. It has everything a complex game needs to remain relevant years later. Typically, a game that tries big things is outdated later on down the line, and simpler games tend to last longer due to how simple they are (Doom). But Deus Ex still has an engaging plotline, variety and versatility in tackling objectives, maps that are still commendable in their size and areas to explore, complexity in its mechanics and RPG elements, and most of all it still has a feeling of being unique in the totality of its package. Usually the crowd overhypes things, but nope. The crowd is right: Deus Ex is an awesome game that is still good to this day. *HIGHLY* recommended.PS. God damn is this game long without feeling like it's just padding ♥♥♥♥ out. Why can't more games be lengthy AND packed with content. Usually titles drag out but not this one: there's purpose to the length.

content:
ry 6
												I remembered having invested a huge amount of time playing this game last year immediately after buying it from winter sale and here's what I can say about this game based on what I can remember,  What I liked about Deus Ex  ;-  Gameplay variety  such as hacking an ATM or computer using ICEBREAKER, using multi-tool to unlock the door, being stealthy allows you to be a pacifist like rendering your enemies unconscious with stun gun or baton (with correct aug upgrades and skills), insta-kill your enemies with headshots with Stealth Pistol upgraded with scope and better damage or simply sneak past as many enemies as possible-  A well written story of a cyber-punk sci-fi thriller  about an augmented man working for an anti-terrorist faction against NSF who finds himself in a complicated, black and gray morality situation with corrupted people and others with best intention willing to do some shady work such as  a noble terrorist leader willingly gives away weapons to some punks who used them to mug a hobo -  Augmentations and skills In my first playthrough (pacifist-run), JC is trained in using Low-Tech weaponry and heavily augmented with Combat Strength so that I could knock out enemies with a baton on their heads while remaining stealthy. Later on, I made JC ♥♥♥♥ing bulletproofed with dermal armor and can regenerate his health at faster rate while knocking out most enemies with single hit using a ♥♥♥♥ing baton because JC is master in Low-Tech weapons.-  This game acknowledge your actions  For example,a) I remembered one time when my superior scolded me for entering a female toilet room.b)  During my escape from UNATCO, at a train station, I stumbled upon Anna Navarre who blocked the entrance to the exit. As usual, I decided to run away to the exit and surrendered to Gunther after finding myself completely outgunned and outmanned by UNATCO forces. But I got curious about what would happen if I choose to fight Anna so I reload a previous save and tried to fight Anna with my missle launcher. To my surprise, I killed Anna with maybe 5 or 6 rockets...and Gunther swore a revenge on me later on. Usually, pacifist players would kill her with a kill-switch in which I did in my first playthrough c)  Before I defect to NSF, I managed to turn the satellites to certain directions and eventually a villain found out about this and sent a group of UNATCO soldiers to take me out. Of course, I reload a save and knocked every UNATCO soldiers out in a building and once again to my surprise, the villain told me that I "won this round" and I'm going to die within 24 hours because they made a kill-switch specifically for me -  Attention-to-detail Admittedly I only read some newspapers, books or whatever to understand the lore and background of this game. But I do noticed for the fact that the writers put amount of effort to put any existed theories into the game such as Area 51, Illuminati and so on. Perhaps, I should read as many as I can in my next playthrough?-  Replayability This game is designed to be played in many ways as possible. Thus, giving me an excuse to play the game for a second round with a different build for JC in the future.-  Soundtracks -  Runs really well in modern laptop, for the most part  On the otherhand, there are numerous flaws in this game such as  ;-  This game is too ♥♥♥♥ing dark I remembered at one of certain points in the game where I had to navigate myself at the top of apartment buildings filled with NSF soldiers equipped with snipers. Even if I did make my game more brighter, I can't see a thing in distance and it makes me nauseas.-  Some cheesy voice acting especially from Asian characters... -  The graphic for its time seems a bit out-dated even compared to other games released at 2000/2001 that I've played -  The dialogue choices in the game seems limited -  Some skills are pretty useless and not worth investing skill point on them specially swimming and hacking Though hacking is not entirely useless, its just that you have to click the ICEBREAKER and wait until it allows you're in and from there on, you can deactivate the cameras, turrets and bots quickly before the timer runs out.Overall, I give this game 8.5/10. Deus Ex is far from perfect but its a well-made game that gives you many solutions to solve problems without resorting to killing enemies.  Hell, you can even finish the boss fights using words if you try to look for this solution with effort

, 2015
												Prior to Deus Ex: Human Revolution and the success of that title, came Deus Ex, the game that started it all. Playable in 16 and 32 bit, this game shows it's age even on the higher graphical settings. More simplistic than later incarnations of the series, Deus Ex, still packs a punch as a fun and exciting game, taking you through the Deus Ex Universe. If you loved Human Revolution, you must play the Original Deus Ex, just to absorb the back story. If you are new to the series, I recommend the original Deus Ex, prior to playing the newer, later games in the series, to get the full back story. All in all, it is still a great game and there are aspects of the game that look visually amazing, such as some reflective surfaces. Still a Thumbs up.

												This is one of the best games ever made, I never got to play it when it was first released, so i bought it in the Square Enix titles sale, because i heard alot of good things about Deus Ex. Was Deus Ex  that  good?  YES   Yes, Yes, Yes. It was even better than I expected *Spoilers Ahead*Deus Ex drives you into a futuristic dystopian world, where you find out that the government is corrupt, that UNATCO (The organization that you worked for) is corrupt too and that they are working with different organizations that hide the vaccine to the plague from the civilians, one of those groups, Majestic 12, is doing experiments with humans and animals, and other terrifying experiments.In Deus Ex you change sides from the UNATCO to the NSF, Illuminati, Triads and the Silhouette. Turns out your brother, Paul Denton, worked for those organizations, and you have to the option to follow him or not, and later in the game you will have to make a critical decision if Paul lives, or dies. The more you advance and play the game, the deeper you go into the conspiracy.The Atmosphere in Deus Ex is just simply amazing, despite the old graphics (which i dont really care about, i dont play games for their graphics) it feels like you are really trying to find out the truth in a dystopian world, and the awesome  music is done by a musical genious, Alexander Brandon, who also made soundtracks for Jazz Jackrabbit 2, Unreal Tournament, Unreal, and many more games. By the way, this game predicted 9/11... when you start the game... you should notice.Deus Ex: Game of the year Edition is a masterpiece. Everyone should play it.

content:
r 21, 2015
Deus Ex is quite simply a class apart.By the time I acquired a PC of my own, Deus Ex had already succeeded Half Life as the cutting edge game of choice and as such it was one the first titles I owned on the format.With so many well realized characters, set pieces and working objects ranging from hacking tools to working vending machines, Deus Ex followed Duke Nukem 3D‘s example by offering one of the most interactive game worlds ever seen.Although playing around with the basket ball on the junkie-owned court in the first open level was fairly pointless in of itself, it’s the little touches like these that gave Deus Ex a reputation for exceptional realism and believability.Ultracool protagonist JC Denton visits many detailed environments over the course of the story and the open nature of each one forms a basis for the game’s lasting appeal. Whether you storm into a hostage filled room guns blazing, enter quietly through an open window or hack the code lock on the front door; there are many different approaches to each situation you find yourself in.This is combined with a satisfying character progression system that allows JC to increase his proficiency in everything from firearms, lock picking, computer hacking and even swimming. Because of the range of non-violent solutions to each scenario, Deus Ex is often considered to be closer to an RPG than it is a straight shooter; something that was a very new and exciting prospect in 2000.In a similar vein to another PC classic Thief; Deus Ex blends stealth, gunplay and a mature cyberpunk setting to great effect and has created an enduring legacy for its legion of dedicated fans.The game’s final quarter is a bit weak though and many aspects of the story form a labyrinthine mess of conspiracy angles when you get down to it, but none of that spoils what is an excellent game and one rightly regarded for letting players take their own individual approach to the task at hand.Deus Ex is the game that taught other games how to grow up and reach a wider audience.Exceptional.Read the full retrospective at my blog »[www.celjaded.com]

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
31, 2014
												DEUS EX is a Role Playing Game with First Person Shooter elements in it, made in the year 2000 by Ion Storm and published by Warren Spector, releaced for the PC, using the Unreal 1 engine.This is the greatest game ever made of all time (PC)No I'm not kidding, lying, or even just saying that to signify it's importance or how great it is:This really IS the greatest videogame ever made for the PC.It has won over 200 GameOfTheYear awards, and many areas of videogame ideas and influence of even compleatly different generas can be traced back to Deus Ex.The concept for Deus Ex came from Ion Storm (Austin) being split into three groups:Group 1 was dedicated to creating the best PC exclusive FirstPersonShooter everGroup 2 consisted of people with a lot of experiance in RolePlayingGames, andGroup 3 mostly included people from Looking glass studios, whose recent success in Thief: the dark project, wanted to see a future version of their FPS Stealth game.And by combining the ideas and thoughts of all 3 groups, Ion Storm (Austin) created the greatest PC game of all time. And when you play it, you won't find it hard to believe.The plot is set in a dystopian world during the year 2052, and follows the rookie United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition (UNATCO) agent JC Denton (hint: YOU), as he sets out to combat terroist forces (the NSF), which have become increasingly prevalent in a world slipping ever further into chaos, through a highly contaigus viris called the Grey death, only curable by the vaxine Ambrosia. As the plot unfolds, Denton becomes entangled in a deep and ancient conspiracy, encountering various organizations (to say whom would spoil too much), conspiracies, lies and twists, that carry on throughout the whole game, as he travels through various environments and cities, from NewYork, to Rome, to Hong Kong, and manny more.The RolePayingGame parts include Upgrading skills and Augmentations to increase JC's effectivness in the field, and choosing diologe between characters, which not only effects the way characters treat you, but also the effects of the multiple endings, and the multiple roots and pathways PRIOR to said multiple endings.But the real inovation in Deus Ex lies within the open-endedness in the levels: It's not a sandbox game, but its levels have manny pathways to the objectives and manny ways to approch them. You can go in all guns blazing, which gun is up to you, or choose different weapons, Lethal or Non-lethal, and try to stealth through it, and because JC has an inventory system, this is possable, although that certain weapons take up a bigger space in the inventory slot, and the re-aranging of the items has created the name "Inventory-Tetris".Remember when I said Non-lethal? Yes it is possable. You can stun, or knock out enemies to make them unconsious, meaning you didn't kill them, or hack a security turret to kill them, meaning YOU didn't kill them. Also, you can skip past the Boss fights entirely, not killing them or knocking them out.Heck, it won a guiness world record for being able to compleate the game and only have to kill 2 PEOPLE.It's that kind of deph you will find here.Obviously, it's not just stealth, and a few areas require you to shoot through them, and the FPS elements are pretty good:There's no iron-sights since they hadn't been invented at the time, although you can upgrade some weapons to have a scope on them, although if you aren't trained in these areas, your aim and crosshair will fumble and spread all over the place. There's no regenerating-health (F that cow-waste) or Heath-bar per say. Damage is taken through to the different parts of your body. Too manny arm shots & you're gonna struggle with aiming. Too manny leg shots, and you're gonna have trouble with movment. Health is replenished by using Med-kits on the different body parts, eating food found in certain places (i.e a drinking fountain or resteraunt), or using Androids found in a few places in various environmentsAnd the MUSIC: holy heck the MUSIC. Just look up the Unatco theme on YouTube, and you'll see how AMAZING the music is.It was composed by Alexander Brandon, who also did the Unreal tournament music, and a few others I haven't listed. OK...Now I've praised Deus Ex long enough, time to get into the problems.It's not perfect. When I say best PC game of all time, I mean that all the things good about it outweigh the bad parts so much, that it makes it the best Pc game of all time: it's THAT good.The first problem is for the modern era: it has aged like absolute COW-WASTE. The visuals are very dated, & it wasn't ground-breaking for it's time either, and that can put off a lot of first-timers.The second problem is with the design choices:Certain skills & augmentations are downright USELESS.Ask any Deus Ex veteran about the "Swimming" skill, and they'll instantly get what you mean. The skill is never needed to progress ANYWHERE in the game. This is the same-ish issue with "Environment training", because being able to use radioactive suits, dull effects of poisons, and things of that nature isn't that helpful.The skill for "Melee weapons" is also debatable in usefullness, because half-way through the game you are given a powerful sword that can kill most enemies in 1-2 hits.Stealth can be a bit glitchy with certain weapons downright wierd.The Crossbow with tranquilliser rounds for instance:The effects on the poison depend on where it hits the body. If it hits the head, it takes 1-4 seconds to pass out. Anywhere else and it takes 5-12 seconds, during which time the enemy can run around, warn other people, set off alarms, & be a downright pain.Also, the final problem, and this is directed at YOU if you plan on getting this, is that it has a VERY small accessabuillty factor.It can be hard to get into, if first-timers don't know most of the flaws.They read all of the reviews saying how awesome it is, and load up the game, expecting a good old time; YOU DON'T KNOW WHAT YOU'RE GETTING INTO. They'll see the character creation screen, put a few points into lethal weapons, and gun handling, expecting to shoot their way through the first mission, only to find themselves out of ammo, and not killing anything.People who expect to play through the game, and listen to all the audio diologes, collect every weapon, hack all the security cameras, and upgrade everything on the first playthrough; It will JUST NOT HAPPEN the first playthrough.You may get into the universe, and master everything in the game, but this WILL NOT happen during your first playthrough.But at the end of the day, Deus Ex still stands the tests of time, and deserves ALL of those GOTY awards it got.You know the saying with Deus Ex? Every time you mention it, someone re-installls it? Yeah, there's a reason for that.So the 2 big questions are:Is it Really the best game ever made of all time on PC? andShould you play it?To answer both those questions simply: YES*And I said Yes with the asterix ( * ) as a disclaimer for first timers.Because there are problems with it that you should watch out for, but get over them, and there really hasn't been a better game then this.Deus Ex also had 2 sequels: Invisible war, and Human Revolution (the latter better well known), and while fans will argue till their mouths are sore over which is better, out of the 3, Deus Ex is the best of them.I  EXTREMALY HIGHLY recommend this game to pretty much anyone into this.6/5

content:
ry 23, 2014
												This hybrid of genres (RPG, First Person Shooter, Stealth and Adventure) is a gem. Despite the years, is a very complex game and introduced a series of mechanics which are still praised today.PROS :- Incredible story (What begins as the simplest thing in the world, ends up becoming a story full of conspiracies and betrayals to the point of not knowing who to trust, followed by a climax that few games can reach).- The decisions you make along the adventure change the narrative of the ending.- Completely open-character to all missions (From the first to the last, you have multiple ways to fulfill your primary and secondary objectives).- Long campaign (If you dare to explore absolutely everything, you will ensure a minimum of 60 hours of gameplay).- Multiple options for character customization (Integration of augmentations that allows you to perform specific actions and skills that can be enhanced at different levels).- You can mold the character to fit your playing style (If you're a pacifist, you can create a stealthy character to avoid direct confrontation, or if you prefer to face the situation ala John Rambo, you can create a real killing machine).- Wide variety of weapons (From improvised weapons to non-lethal, knives, pistols, shotguns, rifles, bazookas, energy weapons, etc. Many of these, completely customizable in their performance).- Various options to interact with the NPC's (Resolving a situation by the way of the dialogue, intimidation or force. Your choice affects the opinion of other characters and their behavior towards the protagonist).- The exploration is encouraged (Many hidden areas that keep items, ammunition, experience points to spend, etc).- Features Multiplayer option (Amazingly for a game of these characteristics, you have the option to play in LAN or Internet. At the time of writing this Review, there were about 15 active servers with people in them).CONS :- Relatively small inventory (Although this is not necessarily a bad thing, but merely strategic. You must decide very well which items to carry).- Some bugs and graphical glitches (Textures that become invisible, walls that inexplicably you can go through in certain situations).An unforgettable story set in a Cyberpunk atmosphere of the mid-21st century. The multiple customization options added to the various narratives that you have for your style of play, ensures that the Single Player mode will be played more than once.My Score: 8.8/10Note : Played it on Windows XP - SP3

												Need I say more? This is the best PC game of all time. Nuff said!For me, the best game of all time has to be Deus Ex. This game combines different genres (FPS, RPG, Stealth and action) into one and it was the very first piece of media that actually made me think about socio-political issues in real life. It also taught me the consequences of choice and how different choices can lead to opposite or even unexpected results. It might be a dated game by today’s standards, but this game actually respects the player by interacting with him/her through choices and liberty of gameplay to reach from point A to point B while maintaining the player grasped into the plot that is masterfully delivered and never feels unrealistic or over the top. It makes you think on the final outcome of all the choices and paths you have taken and can even make you second-guess yourself for doing it. This game teaches you that there is no right or wrong, just different ways to do things.

The immersive atmosphere is rounded out by strong role-playing elements and fantastic music. The only shortcoming comes in form of the clumsy combat system, which has not aged well. content:
y 10, 2016
												Note: All of these hours are played without any gameplay mods whatsoever. Probably 3 hours on GMDX and that's it. Everything else is the original game. One day soon I'll play some fan missions, maybe. Also this doesn't count the hours I've played on disk which too is a lot and I don't leave the game on without playing it, well purposely anyway.This is my fave game of all time and has been since younger childhood. The first time playing through this was the best experience in any game ever. Absolutely mind-blowing. I just wish I could reexperience playing it for the first time because by now I've played over 300 hours on it (including my disk). This and the Thief series are the most magical games to have a first playthrough of ever. This game has a lot of flaws that also add to its charm, so instead of the normal Pro's and Con's, I'm going to have a Charmy Flaw list as well.Pros:+Great sound design+The greatest soundtrack I've ever heard+Incredible writing and story+Great UI+Kick ♥♥♥ weapons (except the PS20)+Characters are extremely memorable+Heaps of interesting locations+Sub-plots and mini storylines+Optional sidequests are great+Non-linear, multiple outcomes, ways of doing things+Five playthroughs worth of stuff to find and then some (not exaggerating)+Perfect length (took me 22 hours first playthrough)+Which means awesome pacing+Multiplayer ways of playing, lethal, non-lethal, stealth, all-out, no augs etc.+Great dialogue system+Upgradeable skills+Lots of replayability+A really good roleplaying multiplayer (if you want it to be)+Shadow based and line of sight stealth system, Thief like but not invisible when in dark+Have to mention UI again, I mean, it's REALLY good+Feels like a real world ("Who will help the widow's son?", "Excuse me?", "Oh sorry, I thought you were someone else.")+Nice plotwist early on+Every character you meet is memorable, every one. That dude shouting holy stuff at Battery Park. That rude newspaper girl in Hong Kong. That annoying boy who's annoying to the rude girl in Hong Kong. That ♥♥♥♥ who keeps asking you stuff in Kell's Kitchen (Used Car Salesman?). Those two lesbians in the club in Hong Kong etc.+Great bossfights+Extremely moddable, just like every other UE1 game, even a baby could do it (except Rumi)+Will update review in the future+Great artdesignCons:-PS20 is useless-Most augmentations are useless-Difficulty gets a lot harder all of a sudden at the end-Default FOV is quite small-Graphics were getting decently out-of-date by 2000-Will update review in the futureFlaws/Charms:*♥♥♥♥♥♥ voice-acting here and there (The Aussie chicks)*Hearing footsteps through rooms*AI getting stuck opening doors*Will update review in the futureSound: 9/10Graphics: 6/10 (graphics were getting old by 2000, but the art-design holds up very well)Gameplay: 10/10Content/Replayability: 10/10Overall: 10/10I can't recommend this game enough. It is the best game I've ever played, easily.

content:
14, 2015
												This is one of the best games I've ever played.It's an action/RPG first person game with a lot of different ways to play. You can go inside a building through the front door, or you can find a back entrance. You can hack computers, digital locks, and security consoles, but you can also get the password somewhere. You can pick locks, but you can get the key from somebody. You can kill your enemies, but you can just avoid encountering them at all.The level designs are just brilliant. They're big, but not huge. You can easily memorize them, so it's easy not to get lost. Some of the levels are visited more than once and it feels different everytime, yet you still remember the places.The graphics aren't amazing and they may look outdated, but they fit the atmosphere perfectly. The music is great and every location has its own soundtrack that fits to what you're currently doing.The story is great and a little bit complex with conspiracies here and there, but there's not much to tell without spoiling it. This game is set in 2052 and it takes place in a chaotic world filled with terrorists, drugs, diseases, and augmented humans. There's a lot of memorable characters in this game, and every single one of them has their own personality. You can kill some of the important characters but instead of failing the mission, it will change the story and you will have to face the consequences.In short, it's a great classic game with a great story and music that combines RPG, FPS, action, and stealth elements with a lot of different playstyles to choose.

												This classic was released in 2000, but you shouldn't be scared off by its age – on the contrary: Deus Ex is one of the cherries on the cake of pc gamings heyday; one of those titles you have to have played.Deus Ex offers a unique and fantastic storyline of conspiracies in a dystopic world, which was made so absolutely beautiful and authentic by all those many details you can discover: conversations, e-mails, newspapers, books, bulletin news, sidequests – you name it. I could write an endless text about how superb the story is, but I don't want to spoil anything and everyone should discover it for themselves.The gameplay also offers a great variety of possibilities to attain a goal. And that doesn’t limit to the question, if you should kill or avoid an enemy:  There is always more than one way and often more than two. And some of the consequences don't occur at once, but later in the game.Believe me: There is a reason why Deus Ex is always among the Top 10 of the best games of all time.

												First of all, WOW. This game defied all my expectations. I didn't expect to be given so many choices or so many possible endings, especially from a 14 year old game! content:
er 25, 2014
												It is essential that you play this game, if you are even remotely interested in any of the following:- Stealth- Role-playing games and character personalization- The world around you- First person shooters- Meaningful player choice- Conspiracies, poverty, plagues, high-power a**holes and other real-world issues- Political storms- Technology, human augmentation and AI- Complex, scarily realistic characters- Lemon-limeDeus Ex was a pioneer in so many aspects when it came out fourteen years ago. The radical choices you could make (one example: you can actually trot away from boss fights, like a hippie chasing a butterfly). The fact that the game lets you play any style you want: gun maniac to stealth hacker, superior smart-mouth to humble and reasonable agent, and anything in between. The near-perfect blend of shooter, stealth and true RPG elements. The intellectual coherence of the game's philosophical and political conversation, most of which is starkly valid today. And just when you least expect it, a subtle touch of perfectly balanced humour.I won't spoil a bit of this game's fantastic story, which is a complex OCEAN of meaningful events, each one offering enriching, frightening and stunning insights into the condition of the world and the nations that live in it.One issue: the crossbow is useless as a stealth weapon. If an enemy is hit with a tranquilizer dart, they run around screaming, shooting and activating alarms for several seconds before passing out. It's useful if you're doing a pacifist playthrough. For stealth, stick with the prod. pro- with the prod.Just please, please don't let the graphics put you off. The game is widely considered a strong contender for the best game of all time. Don't let your addiction to particle clouds and tessellation and ragdoll physics and 9-hour playthroughs keep you from experiencing this sublime game.

content:
6, 2016
												When I first started playing this game last year, I hated it. Not because of the aged graphics and slightly dated gameplay, no. It was because I had huge difficulties finishing even the first level. I didn't understand that the key in this game is to experiment, find a playstyle and weapon-combination that fits for you and most importantly try different routes to reach your goal. But once I understood all this, my experience with this game changed entirely... It became my favorite game of all time!It is extremely satisfying each and every time you complete your objectives in this game. This is for one main reason, which games of today seem to have forgotten:YOU completed the mission on your own, without being handheld by the game the whole time. You found your own route and tactic to reach the objective and complete it. You don't just get a minimap in this game, or follow a questmarker till you reach your objective. No, you have to gather information, maps or drawings. You have to make notes, complete sidequests and search for hidden (and a bit less hidden) areas and paths. Long story short, you really feel accomplishment because you were the one who did all these things, you weren't just following a marker. The gameplay of this game feels a bit old at times, but it is still fun and rather deep. You have a ton of different weapons, and they all fit to different playstyles. They all work pretty good, except for a FEW hit-detection issues with certain weapons. Augmentations are also a major part of the gameplay, but I'll let you figure out that part yourself :)You can complete a level however you want, and there are a TON of ways you can play. You can be stealthy, a ruthless killing machine or an invisible hacker, OR you can go with one of the countless different variations in between. It is a ton of fun, as you can play exactly as you like.I don't have much to say about the story, because it is epic, exciting and thought provoking, and I am afraid to spoil anything for potential new Deus Ex players. Just believe me, it is GOOD, and it changes according to your actions and choices throughout the game. It was mindblowing even it came out, and even today it stands out as one of the best stories gaming has to offer.This has already dragged on for too long, as I expect most people to have heard more than enough about thIs game to know it is an old masterpiece and a legend in the gaming industry. I really hope that, more people will experience this gem for the first time after reading this review. It is, and will probably keep being my favourite game of all time! :)P.S. The game also has a superb soundtrack, really good stuff!

ber 13, 2014
												My best game ever ... and a GOTY one :)I have enjoyed it since early 2000s and finished it from scratch about 10 times! Last time was in 2013 ^^As each game of the series, you will move in an awesome cyberpunk environment, which is as complex and consistent as in the best SF books. Cyberpunk games are usually really interesting because they often deal with a lot of interesting concepts such as transhumanism, bioethics, economy and law.### Pros:- Good story & great cyberpunk environment involving corporations, secret societies, viral diseases and charismatic characters- FPS game with many weapons and their modification, an inventory management system and physical augmentation upgrades (regeneration, stealth, moving speed)- Large number of side quests (you have to speak with most NPC to find them)- Play as a stealthy ninja or Rambo since you can choose your game style- Your choices will have major consequences on the subsequent missions (e.g. death or survival of main characters, long or very quick boss fights ...)- Difficult game in realistic mode, especially at the beginning since you start as a “noob agent”- You will not finish it in 10h (by contrast to many recent expensive bull$hit games) and there are several endings### Cons:- Graphics are pretty poor from a 2014 point of view since the game is OLD ... however, the fan community released mods (NewVision + HDTP) to improve textures and resolution :)- Use the hardest difficulty since the AI can be improvable### Conclusion:You must have Deus Ex in your games library ... just buy it in sales for less than 2 bucks ^^19/20

content:
er 5, 2013
												There is a reason why people commonly use phrases like "every time you mention it, someone reinstalls the game" and "best game of all time" when it comes to this game - the hype is justified for a reason.Released in 2000, Deus Ex has stood the test of time thanks to its innovative gameplay concepts, engrossing storyline and well-written characters, both major and minor. The game puts you into the shoes of JC Denton, a government operative who is thrust into a world of violence, politics and intrigue while struggling to figure out who to trust.The game combines elements of an FPS with an RPG-style management and upgrade system, well-written and developed characters and a variety of interesting locales to create an experience that is still unmatched. Whether you're searching through the streets of New York to take down a generator, investigating a conspiracy in a high-rise office building in Hong Kong or trying to stop a missile launch in the middle of the desert, the game throws a variety of situations at the player in the context of a major global conspiracy.One thing I've always enjoyed about the story, and which keeps me coming back time and time again to replay it, is the range of possible solutions (and responses) to various problems faced in the game world. You can do things that seem counterintuitive or even absurd, and the game will recognize and praise/admonish you for your actions. Want to kill that nosy reporter, despite the fact that no one has asked you to? The game recognizes it. Want to skip the first mission by throwing a gas grenade at the front door of UNATCO HQ? The NPC's remark on it. Wait too long to talk to an NPC? They may have different introductory dialogue based on when you visit them.Likewise, the characters are very well-written, and have actions that extend beyond conversations with the player and into e-mails, newspapers and books found around the game world. All this material is optional, and players can skip it as they so choose.The combat and NPC reaction to damage can come off as a bit "stiff" to modern audiences, but the movement and reaction system in general still holds up quite well, with enemies and NPC's reacting to damage and running away if they are hurt, stopping to reload and changing their firing position or chasing after the player during combat.If there's anything I can criticize this game for (and that's very hard to do), the GOTY does introduce a couple of musical/ambient sound bugs that can lead to multiple pieces of music playing in the same level. Besides that, though, this is still the same tried-and-true Deus Ex experience - you'll play it for the deep characters and storyline, and stay for the different gameplay approaches and solutions (not to mention all of the mods and total conversions!).Deus Ex is a classic, and it's a game I'm honored to have both in my physical and Steam library.

content:
er 27, 2016
												Even if it's not the best game ever made (and you can make an incredibly strong case for it), Deus Ex is, in 2016, without a doubt the most influential when it comes to modern game design. It was the first game to well and truly demonstrate the potential of "immersive sim", a term that you'll read a lot when researching this game. And it's just a fun, breathtaking game. Bold and ambitious and sprawling and surprising. And by God, it holds up.Have you played a game in which you come across an overheard conversation between two guards? Or read a newspaper article or character diary laying around? Or experienced an unexpected consequence of an action you took? Or found a starting-level combination safe with the key containing the letters 0 4 5 and 1? That game owes a heavy debt to Deus Ex. System Shock had audio diaries in '94, RPGs had choices and consequences, but the vision of Deus Ex is a living world, a world that is not just a playground for the character you control but a place where people have to live while you are out busting heads. Combat can and will break out in any setting, but the game shines in Hell's Kitchen. Return from defusing (or detonating) a few hostage situations and you're dumped on the streets of Manhattan, where people are walking around, trying to survive. It feels like a shell of a city because it is - a plague is spreading, jobs are drying up, people are giving up. The game doesn't come out and tell you this in big block letters, you just have to look around and you know (environmental storytelling is old hat in big-budget 2016 games, it was unheard of in DX times). Go to the bar and buy a cold beer for a guy on the job, try to get the bartender to open up about her cyborg implants. Go to the free clinic, where people are talking about the ongoing civil war and waiting to die of sickness. Break into a random apartment and find the bodies of overdose cases. Hack into ATMs and steal cash. Talk to vagrants on the street about how their friends have been vanishing in the sewers...Most of the game is like this - you play as JC Denton, rookie counter-terrorist, who stumbles onto a global conspiracy. Every "hub level" (Hell's Kitchen initially, but there are others) has a central objective, something you have to learn or someone you have to deal with, but you're not given direct instruction on how to accomplish it. You're dropped on the curb and left to figure it out, by helping people who live around it or gunning down resistance or just studying the levels and finding the air ducts (thank Deus Ex for how common they are now) and trapped back doors, and using your skills or your superpowered jumping legs to access them, then go in guns blazing or in and out like a cat burglar. And Deus Ex's most celebrated innovation, so imitated in later games, was the ability to go non-lethal, by sneaking past or using tranquilizer darts or knocking people out with a baton (the last is much harder than the first two). If you don't kill anyone, the game will notice and react, at least in the early-to-mid game.Gameplay-wise, there are some learning curves - Deus Ex uses an RPG system for its combat, meaning if you don't invest in a rifle skill (using points earned from completing objectives or for finding things off the beaten path), you're going to have to sit and steady your aim for a few seconds if you want to hit anything closer than arm's length. The stealth system is functional but rudimentary - it's mostly about line of sight, but sound and light levels factor in even though you have to play them by ear. It is possible and even advisable to stick with a pistol through the entire game (the pros, however, choose the GEP Gun).Flaws? There are some. The voice acting is horrible (and eventually, vaguely racist) but at a certain point, it loops around to being great, one of the game's charms ("what a shame"). Some skills are less useful than others. Knocking someone out with a baton requires a head hit from behind which is remarkably frustrating to achieve. And the story, as it expands into epic scope, loses reactivity and some of the Immersive Sim qualities that made it so revolutionary. But it is indeed epic in scope. They sold the demo on CD at Target back in the day, and there was so much stuff in it that I was convinced for awhile that I'd bought the whole thing for cheap. The game is never less than incredible, always showing you new things, throwing dramatic plot curves and more formidable challenges at you. The soundtrack is pure MIDI synth and befitting the cyberpunk setting, with some wonderful (if proggy) tracks.And the replayability? Believe the hype. The game takes choice more seriously than nearly any other game does, and by extension, more than most players do. There is a scene in which you are cornered by your enemies and a friend tells you to run while they stay behind - when I first played, I thought "this is a game and a well-worn action movie trope, clearly I'll die if I don't do what they say". I left, and later on I found the friend's dead body. Five IRL years later, I decide to replay the game for the nth time and think "You know what? I'm going to take down as many as these mooks as I can before they kill me." So I didn't run, and I killed all the attackers, and the friend lived to show up again, hours later, in a spot where every single playtime before I had run into a conversation about the dead friend. When people say they're still discovering things in Deus Ex, believe them.Deus Ex very slowly came to become the most influential game in AAA development. Games that once would have taken after straight-up shooters like Doom or "atmospheric" shooters like Half-Life have slowly begun to emulate its storytelling in key ways, jump-started by Bioshock's evocation of DX environmental storytelling. Many games have tried, in their own ways, to pay tribute to Deus Ex. Dishonored and Dishonored 2 probably come the closest in terms of going whole-hog in recreating the magic, but they don't quite get there, as good as they are. Alpha Protocol takes its bravery with regard to choice and consequence to new levels. And the Square Enix prequels, well, they're love letters, but they lack the fundamental boldness of spirit, the risk-taking, that make Deux Ex what it is.This game costs you almost nothing now, and once you acclimate to the controls and visuals and rhythms of gameplay, it will reward you, and if you're open to it, you will join its considerable cult. It is an undeniable achievement, a grail of design but also a hell of a game to experience. If you haven't tried it, try it. Choose the albino JC, take the computer skill, and walk into the ladies' bathroom when you get back to base. You will become a believer.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
ry 21, 2015
												About 2 weeks ago, I bought the original Deus Ex and Deus Ex: Human Revolution: Director's Cut.  Really, I was buying Human Revolution, since that was the game I was really interested in.  I bought Deus Ex on a side thought, as it was $1.39 and all the old gamers kept saying "It's a masterpiece!"  Besides, I wasn't sure that Human Revolution would run on my potato PC.2 weeks later, I finished the game, and for a couple minutes just stared at my computer screen saying "Wow".  I know realize that Deus Ex is indeed a masterpiece...although now that term seems inadequate.Set in 2052, Deus Ex follows the story of JC Denton, nano-augmented agent for UNATCO, the United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition.  Basically, the world's gone to heck in a handbasket.  A horribly lethal virus, the Gray Death, has spread throughout the world.  UNATCO controls the distribution of the virus, but, as it is in short supply, UNATCO makes sure that the vaccine gets to the rich and powerful, the ones deemed "vital to society".  The lower classes have no options, and millions of them die on the streets.  As a result of the lower classes's poor treatment, multiple terrorist groups have sprung up, including the NSF in America and Silhouette in France.  As a member of the ANTI-TERRORIST COALITION, your first missions as JC are to fight the NSF in search of a stolen shipment of Gray Death vaccine, (known as Ambrosia).  Immediately, the games environment perfectly fits the bill.  The entire game is at night, or soon before morning, adding to the dark environment of the world.  On the streets of New York City, it seems that the only people are either terrorists, police, or bums.  The entire city feels oppressed and dangerous.  But the game doesn't stop there.  As events progress and truths are revealed, JC travels across the entire world, visiting such places as Hong Kong, Paris, and the famous Area 51.  There are certain open-world areas, although largely without the side-quests that were found in the prequel.  However, this is where Deus Ex's greatest strength is: freedom.The open areas of Deus Ex are very large, much larger than anything we saw in Human Revolution.  Even the linear levels  were so open that I, in multiple cases, had to keep a rule to make sure I covered anything.  The same is true for the gameplay.  Within a level, there are multiple places to enter a place, achieve an objective.  Unlike games of its time like Half-Life, screwing something up in Deus Ex does not mean it's time to reload from the last save.  Even though it is sometimes simpler to do it the intended way, Ion Storm made a way to do it another way.  I'm sure that another player did something completely different then me based on their playstyle, weapons, resources, skills, and augs. The game does have some flaws.  The graphics are incredibly dated.  Upon first installing the game, the game had poor lighting, making it nearly impossible to see in some areas.  In addition, some of the augs are pretty useless, being useful once or twice but never being worth purchasing again.  Other than that though, I can't find a significant flaw with the game.This game is completely worth the price.  There is no reason not to get it.  9.5/10.
