content:
2, 2015
												If I had to go back to my teenage years and choose one, and only one, game that shaped my mindset and outlook on the world at large, it would be a close contest with Deus Ex and System Shock 2. Deus Ex is eerily more relevant today than it has ever been - released in the summer of 2000 and writing this review with the hindsight of 15 years, in-game you won't see the World Trade Center in the New York skyline, you'll read newspapers about martial law being declared in the United States, and deal with a global oligarchical conspiracy that intends to cull the population of the planet through a controlled epidemic. The themes and ideas presented in Deus Ex are not for the light of heart, and perfect for the skeptic and those that realize that what you're presented with on the evening news is anything but the whole, true, real picture. All the world's a stage, and Deus Ex illustrates that magnificently. Deus Ex is an arguably timeless video game that transcends the medium into something much more than a way to spend a few hours shooting bad guys. It is a thought provoking and radical experience that changed my life, much as a masterfully written novel would.It's time for my 3-4 year annual playthrough. Why contain it?

content:
ry 2, 2016
												Do yourself a favor and buy this game if you're even slightly interested. Absolutely incredible game. Timeless level design and story,Pros+ Absolutely tons of customization options; with such variety, few people can really boast that they have played the same game twice+ Narrative is both mature and showcases an impressive amount of depth+ Augmentations, also, offer great freedom in character tailoring; some are arguably more useful than others, but overall the sense of freedom inherent in this mechanic does well to complement the same freedom found throughout the rest of the game+ Modular damage; limbs and body parts experience damage separately, and this translates competently to gameplay (eg. taking too much damage in a leg will result in poor movement)+ The player is offered spectacular freedom in how level objectives and advancement are to be handled+ Level design is applaudable; everything flows well from one area to another, and layouts are generally sensible+ Soundtrack is absolutely fantastic; sets the mood, doesn't necessarily distract, and stays with you when the game is off+ Dialogue and writing is absolutely superb; this is easily one of the better aspects of the game, and it presents well even todayCons- Speed/compatibility issue; this may not affect everyone, but there is an issue with compatibility on modern machines which causes overall gamespeed to increase drastically (there is a workaround, but it's something of a hassle to fix)- Visuals and animations really show their age; these don't hold up well today, but it's not bad enough to detract from the overall experience- Voice-acting, though it can be quite good, is a mostly underwhelming effort; some voice actors go as far as to be terrible

content:
ry 24
												So Deus Ex.The definitive PC experience. One of few games which wouldn't work on consoles at all.It's a cyber-punk First Person Role Playing Game in which you play as a cybernetically augmented special agent JC Denton on a mission to defeat a terrorist organization, all while a elaborate conspiracy uncovers itself through the course of the game. The game starts with our hero arriving onto the Liberty Island, NYC. There, he has to free a captured agent and take the terrorist leader into custody. It is a simple and fairly easy mission, which really feels like a sandbox, where you can test different equipment, see which elimination method you prefer etc. All the levels are open and free to explore, and the game rewards you with useful items and extra skill points you can use to improve JC if you do so. There are always at least 2 ways to get somewhere, even when NPC's tell you there is only one way. You need to be resourceful, and outsmart your oponents. The game shows a staggering amount of detail, as every little thing you do affects dialog and NPC reactions. Walk into the lady's restroom? Get scolded by your boss for doing so.Don't give a hotel owner in distress a pistol? Well, you better come to him when JoJo shows up or he will die.You can talk to many different NPC's to get intel, which will help you in your mission. What seems like a simple bum, can give you info about a secret passage, giving you a chance to avoid sniper fire. Deus Ex's soundtrack is incredible; It's a perfect exaple of old video game OST's: Powerful, catchy and memorable, the kind you'll want to stand in place and just listen to. A fantastic thing the game did, was remix the game's main theme using church organs in the cathedral level.The game itself tackles serious problems, such as which is better: globalisation or isolation, martial law or complete anarchy. Now, let's get into gameplay. The gunplay is very outdated, it feels fairly sluggish and not rewarding. The stealth system, while not perfect, is enjoyable. The augmentation system enchances the gameplay a lot, by giving you lots of new fun abilities, such as higher jumps, stronger hits, or even a remotely controlled spybot with a EMP attack.Overall, the game is great. The story gets deep, and while outdated, the mechanics are lots of fun. Subjectively, I'd say You should really check it out if you haven't.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2014
												Fun Fact: A woman put this game on a chip and implanted i in her skin, that's how much she loved it.Deus Ex, which many of you probably know due to the infamous "Bomb" scene, is a true revolutionary by the literal definition. It's a game people seem to respect more than enjoy, but I disagree. It's probably jsut me, but I don't see its age at all, and I still consider to have the best replay value I've ever experienced with a game. Why is that? One simple word, choice. Deus Ex isn't a perfect game. Hell, it has more flaws than I can list, but it does what no other game I've played outside of anything Eidos has made, it gives true free choice, no illusions, no cop-outs, no story routes that converge, true freedom. It counters the world of the game. Deus Ex takes place in a dystopic United States, whose government has seized control of the planet. Paranoia plagues this world after terrorists attacked New York and destroyed the Twin Towers and the Statue of Liberty (This game was made in 2000, what a coincidence) and an anti-terrorist organization named UNATCO polices the world against the terrorist organization, the NSF. You are JC Denton, a cyborg recruit for UNATCO. A plague called the Black Death sweeps the globe, killing off the Proletariat, its cure in the hands of a select few in power. Suspicions are raised, questions are asked, paranoia grows. Is the government sacrificing freedom for safety? Where has this plague come from? What is the true intention of UNATCO? And that's about all I can say without spoiling. The game has enough twists and turns to make even M. Night Shaymalan blush. The game is everything you'd expect from a dystopic sci-fi fiction combined. Everything is thrown into the melting pot of conspiracy: the MIB, Illuminati, the Templars, evil corporations, Area 51, hushed up alien landings, gene-splicing experiments, the debate of man VS cyborg, and self aware AI are all crucial to the plot. The result leaves you as paranoid and confused as any other person living in this time, and the morality of good VS evil become decisively grey. There is unbound choice and freedom in Deus Ex. Being an RPG that just so happens to be in first person, the game doesn't have a black and white good or evil morality system. Instead, the storyline judges you from the sidelines in secret. The choices you make don't really matter (Some are a tad more advantageous) and none prevent you from unlocking a new skill or getting a new ending. There are an infinite ways to solve a scenario. Facing a boss? You can run away! You can knock them out if you wish (it is entirely possible to beat the game without killing anyone if you try hard enough). Need to break into a building? You can kill everyone and walk in, you can crawl through nearby sewers, you can hack the security to turn on the guards or disable it altogether, the list goes on. Deus Ex is also something most modern games struggle to be, it's balanced. Throughout the game you can score new Augmentations, cyborg superpowers. Each Aug is a choice between two different play styles. Do you want the Aug that makes your footsteps silent or do you want the one that makes you run faster and jump higher (Go with the 2nd actually, it is so much more beneficial for creative players)? Being an old RPG shooter, EVERYTHING requires skill points, but unlike System Shock 2 (A very similar game) the game doesn't punish you for investing in other skills (Though if you stupid and just fully max Poison Resistance and Swimming then you're ♥♥♥♥ed) because each scenario can be solved in so many ways and each way rewards a different playstyle. The choices in Deus Ex are some of the hardest I've ever had to make in any game. No, no choice gives you a different gun or anything and they don't affect the game, but there's deep rooted philosophical questions and ideals tied to every choice. The title is derived from "Deus Ex Machina", "God of the Machine", which means that no matter how hopeless a scenario is, something good will come out of it. That being said, I can not think of a more ironic title for a game as this one. Nothing good comes out of Deus Ex, and each dilemma typically involves judging the fate of mass groups or even few individuals between two evils. Do I allow this terminally ill man suspended in stasis to live with the hope that he can one day recover or do I put him out of his misery? It doesn't affect the game at all, but it's still one of the most haunting decisions I've ever made in a vidya. And that's the genius of Deus Ex, it's a game that sticks. It's story is so massive and so deeply rooted in real life conspiracy and philosophy that it's impossible to decipher in one go. Deus Ex tells a story most films struggle to, it is a sprawling epic that hits hard and never misses. Each little choice feeds into our larger and ever growing fears of our privacy being seized, secret oligarchies, tyranny, anarchy, and forces us ourselves to ask the most important question, "s there any better alternative in a world as ♥♥♥♥ed as ours?" The struggle of JC is one I will never forget, and the game itself created the core of modern gaming to say the last. 14 years later and games, and even the creators of the game itself, are still struggling to surpass Deus Ex. It still has the best and most established writing I've encountered in a video game while also allowing for free choice and having the storyline mold around the player. The game's penultimate moment is choosing between three possible endings, and it's still the single hardest decision I've ever encountered in gaming. Each one is dark and depressing but a necessary evil in some eyes and all 3 tie in different philosophical views on humanity and the state of the United States, which become more relevant with each passing day. It is a given that the difficulty curve is beyond ridiculous and it takes a heavy investment to know how to create your own style, but it's well worth it. There's an old saying on ♥♥♥♥♥ and is in fact written in the Rules of the Internet, "Every time you mention Deus Ex someone will re-instlal it". But I find this gross, as I can never imagine uninstalling it in the first place. It has been and will probably always be my favourite video game, and what I consider to be among the very top greatest games ever made. I don't rate games but if I had to it'd probably be 9/10, the difficulty curve is Satanic on a first playthrough and the voice acting (Specifically in Hong Kong) at times is hammy at best. But that adds to the charm to me, but I know it isn't universal. Also, the soundtrack is beyond Godly,

content:
2, 2012
												Deus Ex is my favorite video game of all time.You play as JC Denton, a man whose body was augmented with nanomachines. He works for an anti-terrorist organization called UNATCO, and is sent on various missions. However, everything is not as it seems.I don't want to spoil the story, so I'll just leave it at that.The gameplay is brilliant. Typically, there are multiple ways you can go about doing any given task. In the first level alone, you can kill the NSF terrorists, or simply sneak past them. Get the code, disable the security, and go in through the front door, or sneak in through a back entrance. Save Gunther, or skip out on doing so. The first level isn't as good as I'm making it out to be, though - it's honestly one of this game's flaws.Speaking of flaws, the game's AI and graphics haven't held up well since its initial release, and the voice acting is... to say the least, pretty bad. Certain sidequests in the game feel unrewarding (with one of them not even rewarding you properly at all, due to a bug.) The weapons aren't very balanced, with the default pistol, GEP gun, and a certain melee weapon I won't spoil the existence of being incredibly overpowered.The game's narrative and storytelling are both incredible by video game standards. It's full of twists and hidden details (a plot-important NPC makes a brief, difficult-to-spot cameo very early on), a lot can be learned about the game's lore from reading notes lying around, hacking into people's computers and reading their email, and just talking to everyone you see. The game does a good job of building its world through the dialogue of random, otherwise unimportant NPCs. Honestly, I wish modern gaming could do things like this. Even the prequel, Human Revolution, didn't get it quite right - Every single NPC feels the need to talk about current events, augmentation, et cetera, whereas the original tended to focus more on other things.On top of all this, the replay value is absolutely insane! Every time you play through the game, things can go very different from the last. Each time, you'll often find things you didn't know existed in your previous playthrough. There are so many ways to play through it that it's worth it to just try everything at least once!Honestly, this game is one of the few I would give a 10/10 rating to. Everyone needs to play this game at least once.BE WARNED: To play this game on modern systems, you will need to get a patch called Deus Exe. This can be obtained here: http://kentie.net/article/dxguide/ Without it, the game will crash on startup.

content:
2015
												A game that makes you think outside the box.Deus Ex is just a pleasure to play, never once do you get frustrated at the game, every mistake is your fault. Is it faultless? No, but that doesn't make it any less of a masterpiece. Deus Ex has such a riveting story with so many intriguing characters most notably Morgan Everett and Walton Simons that will keep you engrossed for your entire playthrough. The gameplay is also superb allowing for many different experiences each playthrough as there are so many ways to complete an objective. You can kill, knock out or simply avoid your enemies, the choice is yours. There's also many ways to get to your objective.The graphics are obviously outdated (but it kinda has it's own charm) but with the OpenGL renderer the game still plays like a dream and I was using fairly meh integrated graphics on my Linux PC, I would go against using the DirectX renderer, even on Windows, runs like total balls. The soundtrack is also wonderful and adds even more immersion to the levels, my personal favourite being Enemy Within. The voice acting is awful, but has a charm and I actually like the way it is as opposed to Human Revolution. Just get this game. It's one of, if not the greatest PC games of all time. If you don't like it.... "What a shame"P.S. I encountered a game breaking glitch where everyone in my save was aggro at me, this could simply be due to using Ubuntu to play this game using Wine, but my advice, save a lot. The glitch set me back 45 mins.

content:
12, 2015
												Some of my friends would say that writing a review for Deus Ex just seems stupid. People already know how good this game is right? They don’t need me to be badgering them to play it! But the sad truth is that as the younger demographic come onto the scene, this is one of those gems that they are missing. And can we really blame them? Just one look at the screenshot or the gameplay on YouTube is enough to tell you that this is not a pretty looking game! Is it really worth getting in 2015?What Deus Ex provides is a lot of mechanical depth. There is a lot of freedom in the way you approach things: you can be a ruthless murderer, a hacker, a stealthy assassin… it’s entirely up to you how to approach the situations you encounter in the game. Also the mechanics, with the exception of the awful crossbow (don’t try it) don’t feel all that dated. Upgrading your abilities and the various augmentations you can make to yourself is implemented really well to the game, and feels quite modern. What I will warn you about though is that you should not expect to be able to shoot accurately when you start the game. If you don’t put points into pistols then you are going to suck with pistols – it’s annoying but mechanically it makes a lot of sense. After all, in order to shoot accurately you have to be a skilled shot!Unfortunately it does look terrible, which is the point that I’m going to put the challenge on you as the reader to make the decision. This is one of the best PC games of all time, that’s a fact. If it was released nowadays with modern graphics it would be winning awards. So if you think you can cope with the outdated graphics, then I challenge you to play this game. I advise that in the opening section of the game you put those points into pistols and stick to the shadows to begin with. But if you can get through that opening level, then you are in for a treat – because this game is fantastic.Please do feel free to comment if you’ve tried and you get stuck or whatever. Or if you were able to break through the graphics barrier and are enjoying arguably one of the finest narrative experiences ever created. I’d love to hear the feedback.

content:
8, 2014
												Some words of warning: this game looks and feels its age.  Graphics are really poor by modern standards and even at the time I hated the feel of the modified Unreal v1 Engine that this game uses, so those who put a high premium on look and feel should stay away.If, however, you can tolerate these shortcomings, you should know that everything that made Deus Ex one of the best games of all time is still intact.  This game pioneered open-ended gameplay and still does it better than most modern imitators: the level design and character creation system enable players of every persuasion to meaningfully approach the game with their own style.  For example: some bosses can be insta-killed through dialogue if thorough players found, via hacking, the necessary code words.  You can even kill everyone that the game's plot absolutely cannot do without, and characters will react accordingly.  The plot is rich and the world is immersive, with secrets that cannot be discovered by players of one build or other, creating a sense of credibility - like Dark Souls (my other favourite game ever), Deux Ex doesn't willingly give up all its treasures, but demands to be explored.In summary, this game started a genre, and it's still the paradigm of the action/RPG because it does so many important things so much better than its modern imitators.  If you're a fan of immersive, reactive action/RPGs, you NEED to play Deus Ex.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2013
												It feels a bit redundant for me to recommend this game to people, but then again why shouldn't I do it over and over again and again.Do you like FPSes?  Do you like RPGs with character and equipment upgrade systems, as well as pseudo-magic systems?  Do you enjoy multiple game paths?  Conspiracies?  Futuristic settings?  Stealth gameplay?  If you answered yes to any two of those.... Get. This. Game.Deus Ex is a classic, in the sense that it is a huge milestone for PC gaming overall.  It seamlessly blends FPS and RPG elements of the day into a combined experience which resonated so well it became a standard in itself.  Newer games like Borderlands, Fallout 3/New Vegas, the S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series, even Oblivion and Skyrim use much the same formula.  Deus Ex may not be the origin of that formula, but it is definitely one of the better implementations of it.  Dozens of games have tried and failed to recreate that balance of elements... sadly including some of the Deus Ex sequels.What makes this game get such a strong recommendation from me though is the replay value.  Quite simply the game is so densely packed with content and secrets that you can have played the game for literally years and completely miss certain bits of dialog or secrets.  Add to that the alternate playthrough methods opened up by carrying different weaponry, investing in different skills, selecting different augmentations, and its easy to see why the concept of spending years playing this game is not far-fetched at all.  Don't let my apparent play-time fool you; I've had the game since it was originally released, and if Steam counted that play-time it would be in the thousands of hours.In short, if you don't have it already, get this game.  Play it once.  Maybe it play it again.  Then, once you're hooked, get a mod that enhances and/or fixes the game and play it again.  Repeat for the next 1-3 years of your life at a minimum.  The last part is likely not optional once you complete the first two steps.

content:
y 31
												A really entertaining game.With many possibilities to achieve any objective given to you, to the point that you might still find new ways to play through it after a couple of runs.An engaging story that becomes stronger as you get to know other perspectives, with tons of little details thrown around the world as newspapers, conversations, and e-mails.Clever level design and mechanics that let you choose whichever kind of gameplay you want to go for. Like taking a tactical approach, going like a spy hacking around security and stunning your enemies, or going full commando.And you're not forced into a linear way to complete each level. Most of the time, you're free to complete your objectives in whichever order you want. And once you clear a "stage", you keep all of your current items and money for the next one, making the transition between maps very natural.If you can get past the old graphics, you'll find a masterpiece.The only con I can think of is that you might need to download some mods to make it playable in new computers, because it will look DARK in its unaltered state.

												It's always a case of "should I, should I not". People talk about reinstalling this game every time they hear it, but do they actually play it? To innovate is good, but to stand and innovate is better, and Deus Ex innovates upon some previously laid down foundations from the System Shock series, but does not stand.It's your choice- it might have been the game of the year for its time, but until then, find a way to demo this game before you truly commit. For some, its clunky mechanics may not be worth it.

content:
y 31, 2011
												Althought Deus Ex broke ground in its day and is frequently listed on "top 100" lists as one of the most influential video games, I find it difficult to recommend today.The freedom to solve puzzles in the manner of your choice is appealing, and rarely has it been implemented so well. Deus Ex is hard, and that's good; it forces you to plan ahead.But the interface is really difficult to use, and the AI is so inconsistent that it breaks game immersion. These were problems when the game was new.Today, the original Deus Ex offers a walk down memory lane for people who played it when it was originally released But for younger gamers who are searching for some PC game history, it's confounding. I would recommend instead another groundbreaking game from the same era and same studio: Thief 1 and 2, which have aged much better.I give a cautious recommendation for Deus Ex, but only for people seeking historical perspective.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
r 11, 2016
												Despite some clunky mechanics, Deus Ex is definitely a great game, I can see why it is one of the, if not the highest rated game of all time. Great nonlinear leveldesign lets you find your own solutions to problems that can be tackled in multiple different ways. Music by none other than the composer who already made Unreal a feast for the ears.But rather than go over the good things that already have been stated a thousand times and list them a 1001th time, I find it appropriate to inform about some drawbacks you won't see mentioned nearly as often:Deus Ex is quite a challenge to run on modern PCs, and this is coming from an old Unreal Tournament veteran who knows how to edit every setting of every config file in his sleep.You'll have to spend some time fixing the game before you can even start playing. It suffers from a number of issues, like uncapped framerate which leads to it running too fast, prematurely cancelling ingame cutscenes/dialogue, screen tearing, crackling sound/music and mouse/cursor issues.There are a number of fixes available for some of those problems, some of which work better than others. The best renderer is a newer, fan-made OpenGL renderer, which you'll find on the net and requires the 1112fm update, also available on the net. This OpenGL renderer makes the game look just like it did back then, and has some important features like a framerate cap. I've also tried the often recommended DX10 renderer, and found that it makes rather drastic changes to the way lightning is handled in the game, usually for the worse, so I cannot recommend it.There's a 3rd party launcher for Deus Ex that apparently fixes many issues, but I don't like running additional software so I did most other fixes by manually editing the .ini files. Unfortunately, I have not found a solution for the mouse behaviour, particularly because it's the cursor in the menus rather than the ingame sensitivity that is way too high, with no way to change it. This makes going through the inventory, the logs and everything else you do in the UI a downright painful experience. And you will spend a significant amount of time dealing with the interface.Going through all that trouble is worth is though. When you're done pulling your hair out trying to get Deus Ex to run properly and scavenging the internet for various fixes, you're left with a great game that has a decent amount of replay value.

content:
4, 2015
												Deus Ex is one of the best accidents I have ever tripped over.  I received this title as software bundle when I bought a video card, back in my early days of building rigs.  I had no idea what it was, but my roommate at the time said he had heard good things.  Boy was I in for a treat.Deus Ex is (yep, still is) the pinnacle of you picking whatever way you want to achieve your objective.  On top of that, you get conflicting objectives, forcing you to choose your path; thus shaping the game into one of three outcomes.  Sometimes it’s easy to get lost exploring the alternate routes you didn’t take on the way to an objective; it’s that engrossing.You are given a wide variety of skills, powers (cybernetic augmentations), tools, and weapons to go about your business; more choices to shape your gameplay.  As you play through you’ll get “skill points” (just another unit of RPG exp), and pick up “augmentation canisters” to establish your superhuman abilities.  You can even get upgrade modules for the weapons (silencers, lasers, etc.).To tie it altogether is a polished cyberpunk atmosphere with a well-written narrative.  The graphics limitations of the time are compensated for by legit voice acting, and AI behavior that’s impressive for the time it was released.A testament to this title is how the fan community has produced patches to maximize its performance on modern systems.  It makes playing it all over again that much more fun…over a decade later.  It is far better than its sequel (garbage), and still better than its flashy (but still good) prequel.Now, for the paltry price offered, why on earth would you not pick this up?

												It's still the best game of all time. Seriously (not seriously. But... seriously)The graphics and voicework that were roundly mocked even when the game first came out now have a sort of retro charm to them.You'll need to lightly mod the game to get some things to work properly (thankfully, there's a surplus of guides on steam for doing just that)The game came from an era where forcing people to complete a separate tutorial just to grasp how the mechanics worked was totally expected.Yet, when you get through all that - it's still nearly impossible to find a game with the same scope of ambition. With so many intersecting playstyles and mechanics. With so much content that any one playthrough is likely to miss a fair bit. With an adult storyline that deals with important political issues in a realistic (and far-seeing) manner without ever preaching at you.It's amazing. If you haven't played it before... you really should.

content:
, 2013
												After almost 5 months of crawling through dark sewers, rummaging through the pockets of dead men, not cleaning my house and being late for work on several occasions, I completed the epic adventure and moral journey that is... Deus Ex. Even though it was released way back in 2000, and had never been considered pretty, I'd found that most well honed gamers still revered Deus Ex as a quintessential, almost religious-like, gaming experience... something I'd never experienced before (in anything.)So, sometime around the beginning of the year, I crawled into the skin of one J.C.Denton, spy guy.Deus Ex wasn't a difficult game for me (especially set on 'easy'), but it was challenging.  To spill blood or not to spill blood? (I'm a natural born spiller.) Should I  help the crazy lady find her cat? (I didn't.) Am I to go east or west? (I usually just turned left.) Will these decisions make a difference, somehow? *shrug*Deus Ex  was a game of Nerves and Patience and Decisions... and bullets.But, especially, Decisions.. which, by game's end, had become pretty monumental. Yeah, I really can't say that I had heaps-o'-fun playing Deus Ex. Sometimes it felt long and grueling. Or dark and oppressing.But, then, that's how it is, when something is intelligent and thought provoking.  And that's why I kept playing, because.. well, it was the object of the game.  I felt that, if I could make it to the end, I might, somehow, come out better than when I started.And, I think I did.

content:
y 3
												We all know the cliche's: cyberpunk, dystopian future, with a morally grey protagonist who ends up entangled in something far bigger than himself. Hell, what am I talking about? We LOVE these damn cliche's!Deus Ex manages to deliver everything we love about the ol' William Gibson novels (which are turning out to be rather prophetic these days), while offering a pretty wide variety of CHOICE. What sorts of choices? From augments to multiple ways of handling situations. Wanna run-n-gun it? Do you. Wanna go Solid Snakin' it? Slither, homey. Wanna be diplomatic? Everyone needs friends. Just be sure to equip the augments that play nice with said play style.Graphically, Deus Ex uses the ol' Unreal Engine. So don't expect face melting graphics. However, for retro gamers like myself, these "old" graphics lend to the atmosphere in Deus EX: a time when cyberpunk was more escapist and less like what we all now live.In terms of difficulty, Deus Ex can be punishing. Particularly if you choose augments that don't work well with your tactics. At its time of release, this mechanic was still very experimental in gaming. Deus Ex definitely plays best on a second or third (or fourth or fifth) play-through.

Every level can be approached via multiple means, and it's entirely possible to make your way through the entire game without using combat at all - tailor the game to your style of play, and it will work with you.Modern games can only aspire to accomplish what this game did over a decade ago.

0, 2014
												A game that holds up well over time - Deus Ex is a first person RPG/action hybrid that tells an engaging story about conspiracy and world domination in the future. For its age, the voices, music, and environments are quite good. All of the levels are thoughtfully designed, with freedom to allow the player to consider multiple ways to complete them, and it provides direction without the hand-holding found in some more modern games.Its only major flaw is graphics, which weren't particularly impressive even when the game was new. There are user-created mods that can significantly improve this, but it is still within the limitations of the engine. If you are able to ignore the outdated graphics, this game will leave a lasting positive impression on you.Also on Steam is the Deus Ex: Revision mod, which adds and alters many of the existing areas and is fun to play if you've already experienced the original.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
, 2016
												This game is considered a classic.  And it's not hard to see why.  Though it was not the first game to try to combine first person shooters with an RPG style of game, it blended the genres together very well.  There are multiple paths to approach each problem, and sometimes your choices have an effect on the game.The game is not without flaws.  There are some very over-powered items in the game that can let you get through it without spending any points in your combat skills.  For all the branching paths the individual levels of the story may take, you're still ultimately shunted down the same end goal.  The AI is not particularly observant at times, and even coming across bodies of other dead guards they will not react (made even more noticable in that you can pick up and movie bodies, but there's no reason to.)Despite these flaws, the story is entertaining, the combat fairly effective and there's frequently ways to avoid it altogether if that's your thing.  Blending RPG elements into FPS games is commonplace now, but this was the game that truly cemented that revolution (along with other classics like System Shock 2).

												If you can get past the bad graphics and clunky combat you will find one of the most unique and enjoyable gameplay experiences. I played this game in 2015 and still found it to be extremely compelling. The level design is excellent. There is true freedom of choice that effects the story. Side characters and side missions are extremely enjoyable. The design of this game is nothing short of incredible. The story is very enjoyable and even though the game is so old i found my self on the edge of my seat to see what the next twist is. The world is so immersive and well developed and I really feel you would be doing yourslef a disservice by passing this one up. The game is also pretty cheep for the amount of content. Doing only one story route the game is going to last around 20 hours and this game is not very expensive. There is also a mod that improves some of graphic assets if the bad graphics really bother you. Finally not to be forgotten this game has one of the best soundtracks I have ever heard period. The soundtrack is really amazing and even if you do not play the game go listen to it on youtube it's awesome. Seriouls this game is a classic and should be played by all fans of rpgs and shooters.

												This is by far one of the best games I have ever played. Not only did the games scenes and backgrounds look great, but the dialogue is incredible. The whole design together really gives the feel of a dystopian future of the USA and the whole world where politics, businesses, and corporations rule all.The story is definitely the strong point. While I played I actually really felt the story coming to life and wondered if this was the same way our world was headed.If you enjoy shooters while getting an RPG elemnt, I highly recommend this. Its a beautiful gem from the minds of Warren Spector and Ion Storm.

												You see this cardboard man who looks like he replaced his scalp with a freezer unit and his eyes with lazer pointers? You hear his incredibly inaccurate thick German accent as he complains about a conspiracy by the custodial staff to replace all the soda in the vending machines with Orange flavor instead of Lemon-Lime?Well you see, he actually thematically represents the possible future plight of being left behind by the world due to physical augmentations becoming rapidly obsolete as new technology replaces it, and you not being upgraded due to the cost and lack of empathy from your superiors. This shatters your self-confidence and renders you irrelevant within society, furthering your frustration and anger that culminates in a hatred for the protagonist whose augmentations far surpass your own. This hate is unleased in the brutal execution of your employer's enemies and finally comes to a head once your unfeeling superiors send you to kill the rogue agent protagonist, fighting more for your own vitriolic feelings rather than for the puppetmasters that care not if you are melted down for scrap like a broken, inoperable machine.So that's something

content:
11, 2015
												"Why contain it?'s cool."-- VoltaireOne might argue what really makes a great game. Game mechanics, plot, characters, visuals, level designs, good marketing move to release at certain time or other nerd stuff. So why's everyone keep telling that a game with broken mechanics, outdated graphics, nonexistent ai and muhconspiracyfoilhats plot is one the best games ever made?It's always delivery. Deus Ex setups setting and drag you in from the first minutes, every time you play you will find something new: new newspaper article you didn't read, new way into some important building,  another chat from hobos about area 51 and stuff like this. Every level in this game is made for exploring. First time i played (2012, so no nostalgia tripping here) i didn't even know there's sidequests in this game. "Kill a prisoner against my orders!"-- Joseph StalinWide variety of weapons with most of them being useless until you max out weapon mastery like it's ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ Morrowind, one-shotting soldiers and randomly running enemies probably make it a bad FPS. But every time you find new weapon mod in some dumpster you're overjoyed like a boy who sees ♥♥♥♥ for the first time. Halfway in the game you're just noscoping with sniper rifle and stabbing people with jedi nano-sword and you're unable to notice any flaw, since plot has no brakes whatsoever and you jump around the globe engaging in terrorism and other pleasant activities."I am the bartender... I am your man."--BartenderBunch of ABSOLUTELY useless skills and augs that are in no circumstances would help you WHATSOEVER, non-existent economy and dialogue decisions once in forever would probably make it a bad RPG. However, with a way that characters react to your decisions and even playstyle,JC's killer quotes and a lot of really interesting stuff you will argue with absolutely random people (this barmen in triad club talking about how chinese dictatorship is far superior to corrupted Burgerland capitalism. I don't even want to mention this cool AI dude in some room in Illuminati hideout) along with sometimes pretty non-linear ways to handle stuff (Only time when game-designers will not let you do whatever you want and force you to bend to the plot by throwing at you invincible enemy and a bunch of invisible walls can be noticed only by true MLG autists like me) will make you forget this too. Not to mention that main character is collest and dangerousestest ♥♥♥♥♥ in da hood (major fault of deus ex 2 was a bunch of tumblr-like characters, even JC will talk some boring quotes of old farts like nobody's business)."I think the black people didn't show up for work at all...suspicous..."-- George WashingtonAnd atmosphere! It really feels like you're secret agent on the run in decaying near future society: uncovering conspiracies, killing corrupt officials, engaging in corporate espionage, lethally throwing soy food at soldiers, blocking enemies with cardboard boxes, using explosives to climb walls and healing yourself by jerking off a water cooler for a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ minute. While majority of good old games is rendered barely playable by time because of ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ interface, already fixed in remakes/sequels ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mechanics, applied wizard science to launch them or what not, deus ex instead of being a barely moving old fart is a motherflipping MC Vspyshkin: game is unarguably pretty old, but is still fun and kicking butt. Once you played it one time you will reinstall every time you hear The Synapse on the internet.And with all this replay value, there's also mods and multiplayer.Considering all that, i can only give this game 100 rusty skull-guns out of 100 and encourage you to play it as fast as possible in case you haven't."my 3 daughters turned up dead, heres your op bonus 1000 credits" -- Manderley

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
16, 2015



YouTube™ Video: Deus Ex: Does It Still Hold Up? 

			Views: 398		

			We take a look at the original Deus Ex to see if it still holds up today. Check out DAKNAP's video here: http://bit.ly/1peQM4g		

After almost 15 years, the legacy of this game still live strong, there are many games that follow the step of the original Deus Ex like a whole feature, games like Bioshock, S.T.A.L.K.E.R, Dishonored and also the new sequels Human Revolution and Mankind Divided, but...Does this game still hold up? Getting over the ugly graphics by today standards, bad voice acting, not so good stealth, RPG and Shooting gameplay, this one still a badass game.Why?The level desing is so superb that even today I still find new ways to finish a level, it serve all the short coming that the mechanics have, is so open that you can roleplay in this game, is so complex that can feel like a good level from a 90´s FPS and you can beat those levels without killing anyone.The Story is complex and a fun ride, if you are a sucker for Cyberpunk fiction this is one of the best tales of the genre, it goes over the cheesy dialogue and the sometimes hilarious execution, to deliver a fun tale, fun in a Cyberpunk 2020 RPG Module.The Music and the art direction, make me forget about the ugly graphics, to the point that sometimes I get so inmerse that I can stop playin until I find a to rest (in game), the levels seems so livable (I don´t know if that a word) that I sometimes seem myself care about the nameless soldiers and goons, I feel bad for them. In the end, the awnser is yes, even in 2015 there are no game that match this one in my opinion, there are many that came close, but at this time, this one still the second coming of Christ. ALL HAIL J.C DENTON.

content:
18, 2016
												In Deus Ex, you play as kleptomaniac supercop JC Denton, whose newest line of bodily augmentations allows him to be superhuman while suffering minimal disfigurement, with the unfortunate side effect of being unable to change his facial expression. In this deeply personal narrative, you will help JC Denton struggle to control his constant food binging as well as his chronic alcohol addiction. In the midst of his stuffed and drunken stupor, he must struggle to avoid crushing dearly beloved pet cats and dogs with his uncontrollably lethal feet, as well as fight a global conspiracy.A plague has beset the global population, and in a future in which Obamacare has never been repealed, health care in America is as terrible as it ever was. In New York, the native population of bums and hipsters struggle to get their treatment (hard to distinguish). Terrorists blow up the statue of liberty, and in a stunningly subtle act of symbolism, the UN sets up a global police agency right over the ruined remains of the symbol of freedom.  As a member of the global police force with the worst police brutality managment known to all mankind, you have been tasked with harassing tea partiers who mistakenly believe that the Constitution is a document which is still obeyed. As you responsibly taser/beat/shoot/blow up in mutual understanding with the community you protect and serve, you uncover a conspiracy to undermind the governments of the world.JC realizes that a global agency is behind the creation of the plague, in a conspiracy to  cull the population of South America  sow disorder in governments across the world so that they may take over. Not an organization to be outdone, they have shown an impressive resume in various feats such as spending billions in research to manufacture laser swords and bringing dinosaurs back to life. Never let it be said that capitalism is not a pragmatic and beneficial economic system.In a globe trotting chase for the ultimate 3D printer, JC and friends realize that the global organization has taken the internet hostage at Area 51 in cooperation with the ayy lmaos and Seth Rogen. JC goes to Area 51 to save his waifu from being compromised, but then he learns that the ayy lmaos are actually just monkeys, which is something no one really doubted about Seth Rogen.In this game where every choice matters, you must choose to save the internet or release the virgins from their prison.9.5/10 It's OK -IGN

content:
y 19, 2014
												There is no designated order of things to do, whichever direction you take is always the right one! Game is built around exploration but the punishing combat mechanics will see you mashing that quicksave key or lose precious progress to a two second firefight that didn't go in your favor. (Bots that aren't using sniper rifles shouldn't be able to instant kill headshot you.) They coupled together a magnificent soundtrack with the most hilarious (so bad it's good) voice acting I've heard in quite awhile. Ye olde countable polygons and short drawdistances (complete with fog) reminiscent to the N64 and playstation radiate an unsettling vibe similar to the first couple Tomb Raider games. Despite an emphasis on multiple interlocking branching paths in each map, thirty hours is quite awhile for the mechanics to start feeling formulaic. It boils down to finding the keys/login information/rockets/lockpicks/hack tools you'll need to open the next door and then pulling up the item or information and punching it in. Augmentations should have been passive and not reliant on yet ANOTHER finite bar of constnatly depleting energy. If you're going to make your game dark as all hell (as opposed to orange) the flashlight shoudln't sap your energy leaving you potentially irrevocably blind. The cache of items you can hold is unforgivably small and the firearms are HORRENDOUSLY IMABLANCED. I put every upgrade onto the assault rifle and it still couldn't carry its own weight. You only need the pistol, crossbow, dragontooth, stun baton, and of course the gep gun. A masterpiece in it's own time. Also there's an irritating bug that crashes the game about two thirds of the way in on the frigate escape.

												Deus Ex's bland graphics, questionable AI and somewhat clumsy gameplay can't hide its age, but its unique mix of first-person action, puzzle and RPG elements with a bold, groundbreaking focus on story and characters changed the landscape, and would signifcantly influence developers for the decade to come, demonstrating that a game can share qualities of film or literature and still be successfull. It's exploration of human nature is still valid now, more than a decade later. If only Ion Storm had replayed this game before making Invisible War... If you're not a graphics aficionado, and don't require the latest in tessellation, filtering, or ambient occlusion to have an engaging experience, Deus Ex may be worth your time. If you don't know what any of those are, this is even more likely the case. Being a prequel with some of the same characters, Human Revolution also draws many call-backs (or "forwards") to this game.

content:
r 21, 2015
 A measly review wouldn't do this game justice. I've had this game outside of Steam for quite a while now:For years, games come out one after another in a specific genre with the sole intention of being better than the last in many fields, or being unique in a multitude of ways. The genre of "RPG" or "shooter" is one that is often explored to the very end of it's capabilities - the introduction of new technology in games like Fallout 4 and The Witcher 3 are games that were and are very easily promised Game of the Year time and time again. But through the embers of blazing releases and trailers, there is a game that pioneered a variety of things in undue time.And a measly review wouldn't do it justice.Deus Ex is most likely one of the best games I've ever played. It's old, unoptimized, and sluggish nature is something I can very easily ignore and regard as setbacks of the age it was released in. Though it's time deteoriorated the mechanics and features, it also gave it an advantage - it shook the medium, and the seismic shock can still be felt to this day. The story is something that draws you in and immerses you into a world of conspiracy. The music is a lovely additive, and you can feel every synth, piano key, and guitar riff even for the time it was composed. The set pieces are convincing, well-made, and lovingly crafted with attention given all the way down to the back bowels of a New York City borough. Deus Ex is a marvel of engineering for the year 1999, and it's accomplishments can be appreciated in the present time.Buy this game and play it through if you haven't already. DO IT.

content:
er 29, 2016
												It's not easy to review Deus Ex. So much can be said about it, but then, so much already has. There is a good chance you have already played and completed it - but if not, allow me to suggest why you should. Deus Ex is an FPS/RPG sci-fi masterpiece, packed with action, stealth, conspiracies and philosophy. You will often find it referred to as 'greatest game ever' or at least in many people's Top 10 list, and you might wonder what the appeal is. Even fans can agree that it’s not the best looking game out there. The enemy AI isn't great and the voice acting... well, the less said, the better. These flaws aren’t very subtle either, they are quite blatant - so if the game has these problems, how can so many people find it so amazing? What defines a great game is not an absence of flaws, but an experience so rich and rewarding that any flaws - no matter how obvious - are happily ignored because they do not detract from the game overall.Nevertheless - do people claim Deus Ex is great just because of nostalgia goggles? Yes and no. Deus Ex pioneered a number of things that have become standard practice since, and so someone coming to it completely fresh won't find it as innovative as someone who played it when it was first released. Despite that, it still shines when it comes the most important part of the game - the story. If you are the sort of gamer who cares more about the polygon count, or skip through all the text so you can get back to the shooting, this might not be the game for you. For everyone else, prepare for a wonderfully rich and detailed world with secrets around every corner. Prepare for characters that will assist you with vital information, only to find out later that they were lying through their teeth to manipulate you into furthering their own plans. Prepare for hidden agendas, dangerous enemies, international conspiracies and difficult choices.Deus Ex is designed so well that despite being very linear, if feels like an open world game. Every level has different methods of approach that can completely change your game experience. Most importantly - your actions have consequences. It's not usually as blatant as 'go this way to save this character or this way to save this character' but far more subtle, with different ideas and philosophies introduced to you for you to decide which one you think should be the right choice.It's my favourite game. Many others say the same. This review, as well as all others, is attempting to put into words something better left unsaid - something far better experienced. It's Deus Ex. What more can you say?

content:
ry 6, 2015
												Deus Ex is set in a dystopian middle of the 21st century, filled with religious extremists and powerful organizations, and stricken by a devastating new plague. The main character is JC Denton, a nano-augmented agent working for an international counter-terrorist organization. But as the plot unfolds, we realize that the situation is much more complex that what we expected.Released around the year 2000, Deus Ex provides outdated graphics and sound effects (even for its time, it was not the state-of-the-art). The musics are simple, and the AI is not very clever. Yet, the game has two major qualities.First, its complex and deep storyline. Various organisations are involved (terrorists, Illuminatis, Chinese triads, corrupt military forces, rogue artificial intelligence, political plotters, etc.) and all are related to each others. So, many 	unforeseen developments will occur, JC Denton will have to find out everyone's true motives, and where to put his trust. All of this allows for an extremely long single-player campaign, with many different levels and chapters. And if that was not enough, the game is full of philosophical and political cyberpunk-themed reflections (freedom of the people vs efficency of the state, the foreseen dependance of our modern society on connectivity...).Then, its extremely well designed gameplay. Deux Ex is a mix of RPG and FPS. The RPG part provides secondary quests, hidden objectives, useful and talkative NPCs, and choices to make that will influence the storyline (several endings are possible). There is also a system of skills and nano-augmentations, that you will have to manage in order to build up your character the way you want. This strongly influences the FPS part, which can be either infiltration or action-oriented, depending on how you upgraded JC Denton, or managed your items inventory. There are also many ways to complete the game, as Deux Ex will almost always provides several solutions to solve an issue.Thus, Deux Ex is a very intelligent game, with a great plot and a very interesting gameplay. It's not surprising some call it a masterpiece, and if you've never tried it before, you should.

Now with that being said, this is an old ♥♥♥ game with wonky shooting and dated graphics. er 28, 2011
												Deus Ex, or "God within" if you wish, is one of those games which defined what a good game should be.  It brings you into a world where every conspiracy you've ever heard of is true.  The Illuminatti, the Majestic 12, the myths about Area 51, every one of them.  Then they ask you, what kind of person are you?  Every choice you make has reprecussions.  Every person you kill has their blood on your hands.  Every door that is opened shuts another.  What kind of world will there be when your journey is done?Notes:  This game is UGLY and requires internet patches to get working on Modern computers, however once you enter the world you won't want to leave without seeing everything through to the bitter end.  The gameplay is solid.  The storyline is great, even by modern standards.  And the world feels amazingly real once you get past the bad graphics.  Don't miss out on this masterpiece.

content:
, 2011
												Deus Ex, despite being released in the summer of 2000, is still one of the greatest role-playing shooter hybrids available on PC. If you're a fan of futuristic settings or the cyberpunk science fiction genre as I am, Deus Ex's storyline and environments should be right up your alley.Set in 2052, you take on the role of JC Denton (JC supposedly refers to Jesus Christ) a rookie to an anti-terrorist organization called UNATCO. But things quickly get out of control and you are soon involved in a huge conspiracy involving various factions - including the Illuminati and the Hong Kong Triads, as you travel over the world to unravel this conspiracy.The game allows a great deal of freedom and various choices - you will also have a few multiple endings to achieve. Deus Ex is a branching game, meaning there are always multiple paths to choose from, you could even choose to not kill anyone at all through the entire game - which is a lot more complicated to do than it sounds, trust me!

content:
, 2014
												There's not much I can say in my review that hasn't been said in the other positive reviews on here. Deus Ex is a first person shooter/RPG hybrid, regarded by many as the best game ever made. Is it? In my opinion, no, but it is still a great game. If you've played System Shock or Vampire The Masquerade: Bloodlines, you should feel right at home here.Let's get a few of the 'bad' things out of the way first, the things I've seen a lot of people ♥♥♥♥♥ and moan about on here and on Metacritic. First off, yes the game is ugly. Look at the screenshots before you buy it. If you don't like how it looks, then don't buy it, simple. The graphics are bad, the character models are fairly wooden, and the voice acting is so bad it's good. Oh, and the default key bindings are pretty bad. But you know what? You can re-map the keys. So it's really a non-issue.Onto the good stuff. This game focuses a lot on inventory management. It's like an old RE title, or Diablo II, where you have only so much room in your inventory for items. So you'll constantly be wondering if it's worth it to carry around the huge flamethrower or keep a couple of pistols and a sword; personally I find this a great change in pace from some games that just let you carry around everything. The sheer level of character customization is crazy. You get skill points, but only at certain points; you gain nothing from defeating enemies, unlocking doors, etcetera. When you find a secret room or explore a certain area, you get skill points, and you get them from completing objectives. Then its up to you where to put them. Pistols, rifles, melee combat, explosives, pickings locks, swimming, healing, and more. You can't master them all (withoug exploting a bug late game) so you have to manage the skill points wisely. On top of that, you can find countless modifications for your guns, among them recoil, reload speed, range, scopes, and laser sights. Oh, and and on top of that, you have several slots for augmentations to your body to give you healing power, quicker speed, strength, defense, and more. But you only have so many slots, and the augmentation items you find carry two for one slot. So do you take health regeneration, or an energy shield? There are so many ways to customize the character to your playstyle it is really astounding.The levels themselves a huge and allow for a variety of routes. In the first mission, I was looking for the person I needed to speak to for my objective; he was to allow me to get into the building where my foes were. Instead I found a big stack of boxes and jumped up on them until I got to the roof, totally bypassing that part of the mission. Later on, if you're careful and look everywhere and make the right decisions, you can even find information to skip entire boss fights. The story can be a bit on the confusing side, but it's well written and takes into account a lot of different conspiracy theories from the real world. I can't say to much without spoiling it so I'll leave it to you to figure it out. So should you get this game? Yes, absolutely. For $6.99, it's practically stealing.

content:
4, 2012
												One of the best games you will ever play.  If you want a surprisingly believable story involving government and global conspiracies with a multitude of characters & a wide variety of skills to upgrade, buy this, you will not be let down.  The soundtrack  is phenomenal, the music matches exactly what the level and setting feels like.  There are lots of skills in which you can put skill points into to make yourself a deadlier close range fighter, a pinpoint sniper, a more proficient hacker, and more.  The augmentations are awesome, you can give yourself the ability to cloak, to see through walls, to run as quiet as amouse, and much more.  There's an abundance of weapons which you can upgrade to give it a laser, a scope, make it more accurate, and more.  There's really just more of everything.  You get to go to Hong Kong, Paris, and even Area 51, the places are very memorable, with the amazing soundtrack to accompany them.  One thing that people would argue as being a flaw of this game, is the voice acting, and while I do agree it's mediocre, it's that voice acting that gives the game even more charm to it.  Fighting with enemies isn't really that much fun though, it's a standard 'click until dead' combat system.  + Believable and gripping story with lots of twists+ Best video game soundtrack ever+ Many skills and augmentations+ Many weapons with modifications to boot+ Memorable levels and great level design+/- Mediocre voice acting- Battles could be done much betterWithout a doubt, the best single player game ever made.

												Deus Ex is simply one of the TOP 3 FPS of all time, the others being Half-Life and DOOM.The reason for such high standard is not the graphics quality, or sound effects or the RPG elements of the game, but the story. This game has a unique story in the game industry.  It makes the gamer keep playing just to see how the story will unveil. It is also possible to reach the goals by various ways, not just the standard go forward and shoot approach. You can approach a goal by sneaking, by finding different paths, or by shooting everything on sight. The last option usually does not work.There are a few places where you can make a choice that changes the story a bit, and that makes the replayability of the game amazing.It is a great game to be replayed every year!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 14, 2016
												Dues Ex is my favourite video game of all time, there I said it. Even better than Final Fantasy VII, better than Tomb Raider, better than Unreal Tournament, Counter Strike and Command and Conquer. It's like totally awesome.So how what exactly is so awesome about Dues Ex? Well everything (apart from maybe the graphics).The Story is truly excellent, an exciting and compelling cyber punk narrative about huge companies conspiring to maximise profits at the expense of peoples lives (sounds far fetched I know)....what's truly great is the game gives you scope as a player to make meaningful choices that affect the story in large, sweeping ways. OK, that's just not true, though the choices in the game feel really significant and weighty, they don't have a large impact on the story itself (for example one choice is the decision between killing an important character in different ways, but ultimately she's toast) but the fact these choices exist was at the time groundbreaking and led to a real sense of investment in the world.The gameplay is satisfyingly emergent, you have the choice to approach different scenarios like Snowden (by hacking), Clinton (being duplicitious) or Putin (by using overwhelming force) or some combination of the three. This ties into the character you have designed in a very natural way (so you can choose to make a cyber specialist if you love the Matrix, a character who can sneak around like Corvo in Dishonoured or, if your big and stupid like me, just tote a huge rocket launcher around blowing everything to smithereens). This leads to a real sense of creativity and fun as well as giving the game tonnes of replayability as it feels deeply cool to solve the same problem in multiple ways.The writing of the game is intelligent, and uses sweet science fiction technology like super powerful AI's and cloning to ask questions concering the nature of humanity and consciousness, the trade off between security and liberty (still very relevant in the digital age) and to what extent (if any) we should avoid using lethal force in the fight against "terrorists" (an argument which came up recently in UK politics thanks to Corbyn). There's some scenes in the game where JC (the protaganist / antihero) will simply debate concepts like nationalism versus individualism or the tendency of power to corrupt (as in Cicero's famous dictum) and his opponents will present compelling counterarguments of their own (and awesome lines like "God was the dream of good government"). The nuanced, slightly ambigous, "grey" tones of these discourses matches the grim cyperpunk pallette of the landscape without descending into nihilism or a feeling of futlity.The game even manages to work as a power trip in certain moments as JC can turn invisible, set huge ED 209-esque robots against one another and (with the help of an overpowered augment) regenerate his health like you were playing call of duty. Yet at the same time the game (despite what some will tell you) clearly does not want you to play the game like a mindless shooter, on the hardest difficulty setting the easiest, most cannon-fodderry baddies can kill you with one shot to the noggin and cute Sir Killalot robots will shred you in seconds. The game isn't perfect, as stated the graphics are average, the game arguably gets easier as you get through it and the choices are largely illusory. Yet it's clever and engaging, memorable and  fresh.

ber 24, 2011
												Rating? 10/10 Why? This is quite possibly the best First-Person Shooter of all time. Brilliant storyline, brilliant gameplay, brilliant sound and music, brilliant everything. It's just that good. While the graphics are certainly dated by today's standards, the game still holds up VERY well in its mechanics. Sneak, hack, shoot, lockpick, blow up, how you approach the situation is entirely your choice. A detailed health system tracks how much damage is done to each limb, and it makes the game very challenging. The game features an RPG-like leveling system. Aside from various skills needed to progress, players also get the choice to implant "augmentations" in their character, giving the player special abilites that they can use to approach any situation. Aside from the main storyline, there are various side quests you can do to make the way ahead much easier. The only thing I think is a negative is that the endings are very short. Still, the game is well worth it. Highly recommended.

r 31, 2011
												There are tons of options for how to play this game. Each level has different threads to follow, and is playable in different ways. For example, you can choose to pursue methods of stealth or use brute force. Your behavior is noted by other characters and changes how you interact with them. Sometimes your actions affect their fates as well. But unlike other games of this vein, it's hard to tell, even after consequences have occurred, which choice was the "morally right" choice. You just make a choice and have to live with it, and follow through until the end of the game. You'll be asking yourself what the designers made to be the "right" and "wrong" choice, but in the end you have to choose who you want to be and act accordingly. In that way, Deus Ex is more true to life than many other games. Aside from that, it's just a lot of fun. It's a classic for a reason-- I most definitely recommend it!

content:
, 2011
												Deus Ex, despite being released in the summer of 2000, is still one of the greatest role-playing shooter hybrids available on PC. If you're a fan of futuristic settings or the cyberpunk science fiction genre as I am, Deus Ex's storyline and environments should be right up your alley.Set in 2052, you take on the role of JC Denton (JC supposedly refers to Jesus Christ) a rookie to an anti-terrorist organization called UNATCO. But things quickly get out of control and you are soon involved in a huge conspiracy involving various factions - including the Illuminati and the Hong Kong Triads, as you travel over the world to unravel this conspiracy.The game allows a great deal of freedom and various choices - you will also have a few multiple endings to achieve. Deus Ex is a branching game, meaning there are always multiple paths to choose from, you could even choose to not kill anyone at all through the entire game - which is a lot more complicated to do than it sounds, trust me!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
y 24, 2016
												There's a lot that's been said about Warren Spector's brainchild, that over-achieving cousin of Daikatana. What I'll say is this: it's dated, a bit janky with some bad (if heartfelt) voice acting and graphics that aren't exactly eye-pleasing.Yet...the very fact that all of those things are seen as lovable quirks by its fans are a testament to everything else Deus Ex did right, all the way back in 2000.And, as it turns out, there is such a thing as a free (graphical) lunch. The Deus Ex: Revision mod is a total aesthetic overhaul of the original game (including music) made over a period of 7+ years by dedicated fans. It's almost comparable to Black Mesa, except the Revision crew largely left the gameplay alone. The purists in the fan community still don't like it, of course, but they're friggin' nerds anyway.Suffice to say even without Revision, Deus Ex is a timeless classic and formed one of the cornerstones of video gaming's adolescent period; not to mention it's just a good stealth FPS/RPG in general for its age. The gameplay by itself could be partially considered a product of its time - the combat while satisfying enough for me is clunky like Bethesda's Fallout model, some of the augmentations are mostly useless and the aug activation buttons take up your entire F-key row. The presence of lean keys and an interactive item toolbar are welcome, at least.If you're not familiar with FPSes and can't manage to get a grip on the (reconfigurable) controls, you will have a hard time more often than not. Actual progression takes long enough that many people who play and replay the game, even veterans, stop after the first couple levels; it doesn't help that some of the lategame levels can be a slog at times. It's comparable to Half-Life 2 in this regard.Those are, however, the only criticisms I can think of. While I'd say there's too much that's been stuffed in to really call it elegant, when the good stuff clicks? It's really good. There's enough meaningful choice and emergent gameplay here to surprise you even after you read this review. Deus Ex rewards exploration and forethought, and while I'm not some jaded, entitled complainer, I'd like to see more of that in today's games. It was certainly innovative back when it was released. If you find the game slow going, I would advise you to simply stick with it. The amount of player choice and customization even in the vanilla game is also noteworthy for a title this old.As for JC Denton and his quest? While it's kind of corny, convoluted and obviously influenced by 1990s conspiracy theory culture, it ultimately grabs you by the collar with its twists, intricacies & personality - and doesn't let you forget it. It's reactive enough to the player's actions that I'd say it's also comparable to Undertale.And the music. It isn't to be missed; rarely do game soundtracks achieve so much harmony with a game as in Deus Ex.Now, this was still back in the Bad Old Days of Pentiums you needed to upgrade every year and action heroes who could be described as Gruff Man or Big Boobs, so while Deus Ex probably isn't the 2000s equivalent of The Talos Principle, it's still definitely a cut above the rest of its time.There is...was...multiplayer as well, but not only did it use the now-defunct Gamespy service and is very likely dead, it seemed largely perfunctory. It's still nice to see Deus Ex-style gameplay in a multiplayer environment, but if you somehow get it working you'd need to bring friends along for that particular diversion.In conclusion, if you are interested in gaming history and/or action RPGs and have a tolerance for old games, play this. You won't regret it.A word of advice, however: visit this guide, scroll down to "Installing Patches" and install the two listed there. Launcher/graphics stuff is up to you, but at least patch the game up.

If you don't know what any of those are, this is even more likely the case. Being a prequel with some of the same characters, Human Revolution also draws many call-backs (or "forwards") to this game.

												Do you own a PC? Yes? Do you like playing games? Yes? Do you own Deus Ex? NO?! What's wrong with you?  You have shamed your family, your keyboard, and yourself. Neither seppuku nor sacrifice will restore your dignity. Only acquiring a copy of Deus Ex will. THE.BEST.GAME.EVER....EVER!1!one!1!  Epic story? Check. Shocking twists? Check. Unforgettable settings? Check. RPG? Check. Shooter? Check. Stealth? Check. Timeless music? Check. Badass nanosword? Check! There's so much to do with so many ways to do it. You have five different ways of performing a task as simple as opening a door. While playing this game you are constantly questioning humanity, morality, and society. Who do you trust and what consequences are you willing to accept? Should you eradicate your misguided and well intentioned enemies or sneak through with the constant fear of death? One way or another, you are JC Denton. Your nanosuit and augmentations put you at Captain Falcon levels of awesome. I played this game in 2012, so there's no nostalgia blurring my view. In this timeframe I also played titans like Half Life 2, Mass Effect, and Bioshock. This blows them all out of the water. The English language is severely lacking when trying to explain the brilliance of this game. No, only grunts, moans, squirms, and drool come close...but even they are inadequate.

content:
1, 2014
												Deus Ex is one of those games that define what an RPG is; a game that allows you to build and progress your character throughout the game and make choices throughout the game's solid plot to build your own take on it. Throughout the game creative thinking is encouraged to reach some areas, surpass obstacles, or even defeat certain enemies. The stealth mechanics are crude, however, the enemies seemingly having tunnel vision alot of times making it easy to sneak past them, or peak around a corner at them, somehow without them seeing your head poke out from behind a wall. The difficulty can be pretty weak when it comes to the enemies, I recommend playing on Hard or Realistic for a decent challenge. For a game released in 2000 the graphics are pretty solid though by today's standards they're pretty primitive, but that doesn't matter, graphics mean nothing so long as you have fun. You have a couple of different skills for different methods for making your way past the game's enemies, security systems and some hazards, but skills only enhance your capabilities with the tools, weapons and items associated with them making them more efficient, but in some cases it is hardly needed, for instance, with Explosives you don't really need skill enhancement that much, explosive weapons already do enough damage to instantly kill the majority of enemies you encounter. (And in the case of grenades you can have plentiful amounts of them.) But skills definately help in getting a better aim faster with ranged weapons, and modding and enhancing said weapons is a nice touch when you can stick a "silencer*" on an Assault Rifle or a Sniper Rifle, turning a sniper into a quiet one-shot-kill weapon most of the time. (so long as you aim for the head) Ontop of that, slow reloads on your shotguns? There's a mod for that. Trouble with the gun's shots hitting your target? There's a mod (and skills) for that. Want to turn a pistol into a marksman weapon? There's a scope mod for that. Multiplayer I haven't played much of but I vaguely recall it being fun but also confusing, can't really comment on it, but I can certainly comment on the actual game itself: A classic that has stood the test of time.9/10*Unlike real life -suppressors- the silencer in the game actually makes weapons silent to enemies.

ry 19, 2015
												Real conspiracies. Severe consequences. Intense action role-playing.Writing this takes me back to pre-Steam times. I played this game for the first time back in year 2001 and later on made either a partial or full replay every 3-4 years. Everytime I was overwhelmed and impressed with immerse story that takes you all around the world, all these well written characters, movie-like screenplay and captivating sound environment. I would spend many hours looking in every corner, putting the pieces back together and digging the story and it's background, discovering secret areas, thinking about philosophical questions hidden between the lines - pretty much embracing Deus Ex. (A huge portion of this was successfully recreated and implemented in Human Revolution - which I would like to recommend as well). Deus Ex is among my few best games I have ever played, literally a diamond of a game. Everything about this game is exceptional: moral choices and it's consequences, elastic gameplay, the atmosphere, all the ambiance you can experience. Everything, in a way modern games try to achieve with mixed success.Did I mention replay value? Tremendous. Someone mentioned Deus Ex and I reinstalled deciding to not to give up and push on till I see the credits! Game from year 2000 won with growing line of brand new titles. To my amazement I managed to discover three new hidden areas and finding them after several replays was really rewarding. Has it aged well? For 2000 game, hell yes, only of you can handle near millennial style of boxy graphics and somewhat wooden animations, but really it doesn't matter and shouldn't bother you since backbone and writing of this game is really solid and presents still open and actual questions like: global government, NWO, infiltration, genetic enchancement and augmentations knocking to our door. "Trust no one. Question everything" - Play Deus Ex and soak in and embrace the night.
