content:
ry 17
												Deus Ex is one of the most influential games ever made. No genre describes this game as it seamlessly blends action, stealth, RPG and story elements into one unique game. It's safe to say that this is the best game in the Deus Ex series, with Human Revolution taking second place in my opinion.Firstly, I will talk about the gameplay. The game has three difficulty settings, and I prefer to play on normal. It isn't ridiculously difficult, but first-time players will be challenged and may find the game rather punishing. You really have to explore every inch of the game because if you run out of lockpicks or multitools, things are going to take a turn for the worse. But I think that this encouragement to explore really enhances the experience. This game makes you think. You can't just run gung-ho into combat because you WILL die. Instead, it makes more sense to creep around in the shadows with a melee weapon or sniper rifle, picking off unaware foes and dragging their bodies into a dark corner where nobody can see them. However, the stealth is often very inconsistent. There was one time when I sniped off a guard from afar and his comrades didn't even notice, but there was another time when I did the same thing and everybody was immediately aware of my exact position. Thankfully, there's always another way around an objective, and this open-ended level design is a hallmark of this series. The game has RPG elements such as skills that let you specialise your character, and a wide range of augmentations that allow you to regenerate health, see through walls, go invisible and even detonate rockets as soon as an enemy fires them. These elements force you to choose a playstyle that suits you well, and caters to any player's needs. Want to go in charging like a living tank? The ballistic sub-dermal armour will let you take more damage without dying. Want to sneak in the shadows like a ghost? The cloak aug will stop enemies from seeing you. I found the most useful aug was regenerating health, because you will frequently take damage from hazards littered liberally around the environments. Choices matter a lot in this game. For example, if you tell Jaime Reyes to stay in UNATCO, he meets you later in Paris and gives you a killphrase that allows you to bypass the fight with Gunther Hermann. This brings me to my next point: this game has the BEST BOSS BATTLES OF ANY OTHER GAME EVER. You don't even have to do them. You can just run right past. You can even kill bosses in earlier levels so you won't have to do them later on. I wish other games used this mechanic!         Not everything is perfect, though. This game has plenty of issues. I have encountered many bugs, from getting stuck in doors, to characters transmitting me the same message ten times, to using my jumping aug to jump through the ceiling of the 'Ton hotel and then landing on an invisible floor 3 feet above the ground. But to be honest, this doesn't detract from the experience and in some cases even enhances it. I mean, it would be fairly logical for me to be able to get stuck inside a repair bot, wouldn't it?  Maybe not. In any case, this is a fun game to play.       Now I will talk about the presentation. This game is 17 years old, and graphically it really shows its age. Character models look blocky, textures look blurry, and the environments are so ridiculously dark that I couldn't see things a metre in front of me in some cases. But the game is still really immersive, and although some sci-fi elements are REALLY far-fetched, the game still feels real. The political themes of the game mirror real life and in some cases, the game even feels like a social commentary. This results in a game that is still immersive despite its laughable graphics, and is probably the number one example of "graphics aren't everything".

Product received for free
A role-playing sci-fi game with loads of features, a very interesting story, great music, and iconically bad voice acting.I couldn't get into it the first few times I played it and I disliked it from the first few hours of gameplay but after a few recent restarts I learned to appreciate it. There are loads of gameplay features but much of them are pretty broken if not outdated, which was initially one of the main reasons I disliked the game at first.There are a multitude of skills you can upgrade that are given to you right from the beginning: Lockpicking, Electronics, Medicine, Computer, and Swimming. The Weapon Skills in the same window are Heavy, Pistol, Rifle, Low-Tech, and Demolition. If you don't know what weapon you just got benefits from what skill, you can check the info on its description.I realized that the skills aren't actually mandatory for the game's progression and I'm pretty sure you don't even need to upgrade any to beat the game; they're there to make certain play-styles easier on the player so should you obtain enough points to upgrade. For example, Lockpicking just decreases the amount of lockpicks you use for a heavily-locked door, Computer allows you to hack computers if you don't feel like or just haven't found the login/password for a terminal, and all the Weapon Skills increase damage & accuracy. As a good role-playing game goes, you can't legitimately max out everything in one playthough, at least not as far as I know anyway.Fancier upgrades can be found in the game via augmentation canisters that are located throughout the game with various functionalities that all eat up your energy meter when used. You're not a shake flashlight so you have to recharge your energy meter when appropriate via these recharging robots or a certain recharge item you can find throughout the game.Augs consist of things like the ability to lift heavier objects, run faster, EMP shield, and more. Each canister gives you a choice of what two augs you want to install to its desired slot. Unfortunately you can't replace already installed augs so you need to choose wisely on what you want to have. You can  quicksave/quickload to see how one augmentation works if you must. There are also upgrade canisters you can find that upgrade said installed augs for improved functionality.During my mostly-stealthy, mostly-non-lethal playthrough I found only a select few augs to be of any use and some I regret installing.Taking damage is pretty unique in this game as each limb has their own HP.If your legs' HP reach 0 you'll have to crawl instead of walk. If your arms', then your efficiency with weapons is decreased. If the head's or torso's reach 0, then you die. With medkits you can heal each limb individually. Miraculously you can practically regrow your limbs via food & drinks though you'd have to consume a hefty ton of those for that idea to come to fruition.Much of the game has you doing things manually with one of these things being the inventory. There's no inventory-tetris in the game despite several items taking up more than one space which can be a real pain sometimes. You can't rotate items so if something takes up 2 squares of inventory space horizontally then you'll have to make 2 empty horizontal slots yourself since there's no auto-arrangement when it comes to inventory space. It's a bigger nuisance if you're trying to pick an item up but you don't know how much space it needs so your only choice is to ignore the item altogether or drop several items on the ground hoping you've made enough room to even pick it up.One of the selling points of the game is how there really are multiple solutions to problems as advertised.Door's locked? You can lockpick it. No lockpicks? You can shoot it, hit it with a melee weapon, or use explosives depending on whether or not the door's weak enough. Is the door immortal? Either find a key or find an alternate path. The game's designed for each level to have at least more than one way to get through something save for one part of the game. You're even rewarded with supplies and usually skill points for exploring nooks and crannies.And of course you can go about the entire game using non-lethal measures.The gunplay is a little unreliable until you upgrade the appropriate weapon skill and/or you upgrade the weapon of choice with upgrade mods that you can find throughout the game. It's even more unreliable to go guns blazing in the beginning as well. Your crosshair is spread wide open until you stand still for a bit but even then the bullet can look like it just went outside of the crosshair diameter. For some reason the crosshair thing applies even to melee weapons, even if it's not visibly shown. I'm not entirely sure how the gunplay is played out if I upgraded their appropriate weapon skills since stealth was so strongly encouraged and that's how I often like to play games like this.The AI awareness when you're sneaking about is weird. They're certainly "functional" but how they work can easily shatter one's suspension of disbelief; they don't often hear gunshots when it looks like they should, sneaking up to them & colliding with their models doesn't alert them, and etc. etc. For some reason, to do a 1-hit takedown, lethal or non-lethal, on most humanoid enemies you have to hit them on their lower back for it to work. Hitting the head steathily just treats it as regular damage. You also have to collide with their bodies as you swing your weapon an inch above the belt region, otherwise it's just relied on RNG on whether or not you hit the desired spot.The tranquilizer darts are said to be "quiet" but it's hardly so when it doesn't instantly take them down and the enemy just runs in circles until they finally go down. Only if they're alone (as well as not being near an alarm button) will it be considered "quiet" as no one will be alerted while they run around until they drop. Even if an alarm is tripped in any manner it's easy to just hide and wait until the alarm silences and then everyone just goes about their usual stuff.You can loot a body, whether unconscious or dead, and can only pick them up when their inventory is empty. But there's no point in picking bodies up aside for comedic purposes since no one cares if there's a new body on the floor; all anyone cares about is if they "witness" the attack itself.The story is very interesting to say the least even if they are often portrayed through silly voice acting. Depending on what you do throughout the game, certain dialogue pieces change, characters die, characters appear at a different time, and so on. Sadly the story as a whole doesn't change no matter what you do aside from the endings.I found several bugs & glitches throughout the game. One that can potentinally ruin someone's playthrough are possible CTD's during critical parts of the game, though I've only come across that once. Basically, each time I loaded up this particular save file the game would crash immediately after the helicopter I saw left the area so I had no choice but to load up the next recent save file.Despite the FPS-looking nature of the game it's overall a role-playing game, though it looks like you can treat it like an action game if you so desire.I played the game without mods and it's been overall fine if you can deal with the bugs & small text.You'd also have to look past the outdated/broken graphics & certain functionalities of some gameplay mechanics and shoddy voice acting but if you can get by those then there's a better chance that you can see the game's probably not just something people put on nostalgia-glasses for to praise it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
1, 2014
												In the opinion of many professional (and unprofessional) video game reviewers and commentators, Deus Ex is hailed as one of the singular greatest arguement for the greatest game of all time. The in-depth story is as long as it is captivating, taking the player on a global journey from New York City, to Shanghai, to Paris and California and a rather surprising ending location. The story is unparralled in it's depth and creativity, despite broaching a genre which has been entrenched in many fictional works. The gameplay is superb, and serves as a model for close to every FPS/RPG succeading it. Ultimately, the excellence of this work is somewhat inhibited due to the aged graphics which it holds, the faces being a notable point of contention. But this minimially detracts from the experiance, and the atmosphere is unparalled despite this. However, Deus Ex belonged to a generation of games helmed by Warren Spector and other early PC innovators. This collection of programmers and coders worked on some of the most renowned games of all time, System Shock 2 (1999), Thief (1998), and other celebrated classics. They run in tandem with a more focused RPG genre, led by the Fallout games, Elder Scrolls games and other Dungeons and Dragons isometric games largely held as the culmination of masterpieces for the PC. In a sense, Deus Ex is sort of the harbinger of a new age for PC games, one which sort of loses a touch which System Shock 2, Thief and Deus Ex had, and this is inherent within the sequel, which abandons many of the tropes which made Deus Ex a masterpiece. Morrowind serves a similar function albeit for the RPG side, with Oblivion and Skyrim notably streamlining many RPG aspects within that particular game. That is not to say the sequels for Deus Ex are bad. On the contrary, Invisible War is good - but strange. Human Revolution however is noteworthy and worth a playthrough, if only for the grandiose set-up it leaves for this game. Overall this series is one of the innovators within gaming, and thus should be worth consideration.

content:
19, 2016
												Deus Ex is truly a masterpiece. Despite the name there is no Deus Ex Machina effect whatsoever - everything is logical and consequential and every detail is a piece of whole - user's password can tell you about his life more than you can hear from anyone, organisation name contains a key to it's entrance, and internet adresses hint major plot twist. The world of demolished Lady Liberty is surprisingly and eerily real both in it's behaviour and as a very possible future of ours. It also one of the most stylish worlds out there. Without overusing design cliches and descending into self repetition it keeps cold, metallic demanaur faintly lit by distant LED lights and blue ROM module colloids from the start to the end. And the wonderful tracker soundtrack by Alexander Brandon and Michel van de Bos is making perfect - transcendent.As for the gameplay. On the first glimpse arsenal is quite poor - less than ten types of firearms, couple of throwables, few melee choices and array of tools - but what this game about is you, as a player, as a character. Main tool in your arsenal is your head - numerous ways to approach the objective are only multiplied by your skills and the most useful tool in game - augmentations, which allow you to perform superhumane tasks such as invisibility, wind speed combined with impossible jump height or even projectile-stopping nanite shield - everything is in your hands. But beware that you are limited not only by supply of bioelectricity, but also with finite augmentation possibilities. The brighter you burn the faster you expire and one possibilities take take place of anothers. So at the end your head - is your main tool and weapon, not even the GEP gun.Don't be scared off by strange and old look of unreal engine or somewhat obsolete (i'd say more outmoded though) futurology - game holds it's mark to this day and is, and never cease to be a truly amazing and unique experience. Give it a shot. And don't play it like game - feel it, live in it. Because it's how it's meant to be. Because it's worth it. And remember - trust nobody, question everything.

content:
14, 2015
DEUS EX - Every time you mention it, someone will reinstall it.Three years after I first played Deus Ex: Human Revolution and enjoyed it immensely, it was finally time for its big brother. I tried the original Deus Ex a few years ago, but I just couldn't get passed its outdated visuals (including New Vision) and especially its awful animations. Which I think is probably typical for the Deus Ex series, since Human Revolution also wasn't a looker to begin with. But I suppose I kinda matured in terms of gaming in the last two years, because when I started Deus Ex again a few months ago, the visuals didn't bother me.But enough about me. Besides the convincing dystopia future with its own share of society problems dripping with atmosphere, I needed some time to adjust to the gameplay. Because it has been quite some time that a game didn't spoon-fed me how to play the game or which way to go with a huge pointer on-screen. Overwhelming at first, but the level of player freedom makes you comfortable very quickly. You get a relatively big area each level where you can go where ever you please, do whatever you want in a manner you find appropriate. The excellent level designs makes sure of that. Later on, based on the augmentations you choose, you get even more options that suit your play style. No wrongs or rights.+ Excellent level design, a lot of player freedom, all roads lead to Rome.+ Not a single moment of holding hands, just good ol' fashioned exploration and finding the way on your own.+ Dystopia cyberpunk future and its problems are represented very well and convincing. + A great story to boot that rarely to never loses its grip.+ A lot of choices and consequences that can make your life later on easier or harder.+ Great atmosphere and an even better soundtrack.- Ugly face animations, probably even for 2000 standards.- Mediocre/static voice acting, except Bob Page whom I thought sounded excellent.- Stupid AI, though understandable considering it's 15 years old now.I still prefer Human Revolution (first love and all that), but now I can understand where most of its brilliance comes from. If the next Deus Ex, Mankind Divided, can combine the strengths from both Deus Ex 1 and Human Revolution, and somehow iron out their respective little flaws, Mankind Divided will be a very, very unforgettable experience. The hype is real.9/10

content:
25, 2015
												I want to tell you a story. It has spoilers, so consider yourself warned.My JC Denton was a good agent. In the field, he was an intelligent, efficient snipe-happy hacker, with a pistol for emergencies. (Side note: Silenced sniper rifle + laser-sight pistol, both at Advanced skill level =OP.)However, when he infiltrated the building Paul Denton told him to to show him that UNATCO was corrupt, my JC mixed up his objectives and went to the roof, where the satellite dish he was supposed to change if Paul was correct was located, instead of the basement, where the proof was. This was a bit of a dilemma.Then my JC Denton had an epiphany.He realized that he would work for whichever side allowed him to shoot, loot, and hack as much as possible. So right then and there, my JC hacked the satellite dish and looted what was inside, betraying his country for some immediate cheap thrills. Don't get me wrong, he wasn't psychotic; my JC was just extremely vindictive, self-righteous, and challenge-seeking, and he had a lot of guns.He then went through the rest of the game, shooting and looting and hacking all over the place, and when the time came, he took the only sensible option and merged with Helios.Deus Ex has a lot of problems. It looks awful, there aren't enough character options for the action-oriented player, the voice acting is atrocious, and some enemies have way too much health (lookin' at you, greasels). However, any game with this amount of player choice and understanding of the player (one time, when lost and trying to leave a cathedral, I walked up to a French chef and JC promptly asked how the hell to get out of there) deserves whatever recommendations it can get.Seriously though, f*ck all the transgenics.

content:
6, 2015
												This game is one of the best I've played. Before I got into sandbox games like The Elder Scrolls and Fallout series of games I played Deus Ex. This plays differently than both of those titles, but it does sanbox play in its own way very well. The game can be advanced in any way you desire, be it stealth gameplay, run&gun, smash things with a crowbar, hacking terminals, killing everything you see, non-lethal takedowns, etc...You also have access to a rudimentary skill system that allows you to focus your expertise in whichever areas you so choose. You can be extremely skilled with handguns or relatively skilled with rifles, heavy wepons and melee weapons. You can increase the effectiveness of your medkits to heal you for more or focus on avoiding combat by getting more usefulness out of your lockpicks and multitools (high tech lockpicks for security doors and cameras).You will gain access to augmentations for your character as well. These are upgrades that have an active effect when you need it most at the cost of bio-electrical energy (basically a secondary resource like mana). These augs can be chosen from one of two per body part. You can augment your arms to deal tremendous melee damage or give you the strength to move heavy objects. You can augment your legs to give you faster movement speed or increase the height you can jump as well as ruduce falling damage. You can augment your lungs to allow you to hold your breath for longer periods underwater or to filter harmful substances from poisoned or irradiated areas. You can augment your skin to reduce damage from projectile wepons or from energy/fire weapons. There are many different combinations you can choose from, and each will help a particular style of gameplay. The choices are left entirely to you.Then there's the story. I won't give away spoilers, but know that nothing is what it seems nor is anyone who they really seem. There are many great twists and turns beofre you reach the end, and there are several different endings depending on your actions throughout the game. You can advance the story any way you want through your actions and dialogue choices. Deus Ex does this very well by allowing you to decide for yourself what actions you want to take in any given situation. Did that guy betray you? You can trust that he won't do it again, not trust him and never deal with him again or kill him for screwing you over. For every choice you make there will be some sort of effect on some aspect of the game, be it causing you to switch alliances or just a quirky dialogue change. Due to this there is a great deal of replayability that will keep you playing through over and over to see what would happen if you did things differently.Remember that this game was released in 2000, so don't expect hyper-realistic visuals and sound effects or nop-notch voice acting. What this game does best is to deliver a fun, memorable gaming experiece that sets it apart from your average yearly installment of CoD.BE FOREWARNED: To those who come from playing games like The Elder Scrolls and Fallout you will have to leave items on the ground never to be seen again. There is no storage nor are there vendors. The game revolves around you only taking what you inetend to use. It kills me coming back to this game after playing Skyrim. I hate leaving rocket launchers and flamethrowers behind due to my compulsive desire to take everything, but after a little while you get accustomed to it. As you increase your skills in certain areas you will find weapons you don't specialize in are less desirable due to their ineffectiveness and lack of monetary value. I specialize in handguns, and in leveling my skills in that area the usage of handguns becomes more fluid. I become more accurate, can use them more effectively while running, deal more damage with them, etc.., while with a sniper rifle I would have to stand still for a good ten seconds to get a good bead on my target, have a hard time aiming and deal less damage. It gets to the point where when I see a rocket launcher lying on the ground I don't even want to pick it up.I would highly recommend Deus Ex to anyone who enjoys a game with a good mix of story, solid gameplay, freedom of choice, decision making and consequence. 10/10 a classic.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
17, 2015
												For those of us who remember the N64, Goldeneye 007 was up there with Ocarina of Time, and Super Mario 64 as one of the most popular games of the system. Deus Ex reminds me in many ways of Goldeneye.The gameplay is unmatched. Every level presents new scenery and new challenges. Just like in Goldeneye, you have various objectives that must be completed. And to complete the objectives, you have to deal with enemies as well as many other hazards, There are multiple ways to get to the objectives; do you clear the resistance or do you use your tools to get through the securely locked doors? This game features level ups in the form of augmentations and skill points. Skill points are gained by finding secrets and clearing objectives and can be used to better your skills, while augmentations are enhancements that can enable you to do things like healing, causing enemies to blow themselves up with rockets, or seeing through walls! You find these in canisters; found throughout certain areas. It's a fun game and for all you diehard Goldeneye fans (and even if you aren't), you'll love this game. Quite frankly, I don't know why anyone wouldn't. So go and get it.

content:
er 14, 2014
												Lets conduct a procession for what is irrefutably one of the greatest things ever conceived. You had bacon, Michael Jordan, the Eagle Speedster and now you have this. Like many games it has problems. Unlike many games it manages to completely overthrow those issues to deliver a superlative experience that you will never forget. Regardless of whether it's the godly soundtrack, the bizarre characters, the grandiose level design or anything else in particular that tickles your fancy, ultimately this work has an aura that'll grip and transform you.

												A classic game that's aged well, and the dated graphics don't stop it from being gripping and fun. content:
1, 2015
												Alot of people spam this game when you ask them what they consider the best game ever made is, but is it true? Ill toss my opinion in the sea of maymay reviews and BOMBs etc etcIll start off with the badThe gameplay is clunkyThe graphics are ♥♥♥♥The game will most likely run like ♥♥♥♥ without a fanmade patch or fix like DEUSEXEThe voice acting is bad and can have some very bad actors here and thereNow for the goodThe voice acting is bad and can have some very bad actors here and there (its one of those wierd quirks in the game that makes it enjoyable and unique, not just a bunch of british people making everything sound dramatic)The graphics, while bad, have a style to them that I havent seen matched in any other game, not even the subsequent Deus Exes... its very dirty and cool temperant with all the blues and greys, with vibrant colors sprinkled across the levels to keep it just interesting enough to the eyeThe gameplay is indeed garbage, but it has a charm to it as well, it hard to explain and very subjective, but you might find yourself laughing your ♥♥♥ off after you smack a guard in  the back of the head with a baton and he falls flat on his faceThe real gem of the game is the story and writting as well as characters and twists in the plot. Its one of those games where you never want to really finish it because its so good, you dont want to see the ending come just yet. Ive reinstalled 3 times already and still havent seen the endingThe level design is very open and large for its time, Im always impressed at how many paths are crammed into the level without being to obvious. This is a short review, Its my favorite game of all time, it has flaws, but those flaws give it some character. I highly suggest you hop into it if you ever have a weekend to get ingulfed in a game. The first 2 levels arent top tier by any means, so dont let  them drive you off like they made me for awhile. I played this in 2014, and loved it. So dont believe the very few haters of this game when they say only people who played it when it came out like the game.

												Deus Ex hasn't aged very gracefully, but it's still a blast to play. The story is compelling, the visuals aren't that bad, the music is dynamic and addictive, and the gameplay is very non-linear. You can be stealthy or you can go in guns blazing. There are lots of ways to complete missions and lots of secrets to find. Cannot recommend this game enough.

												This game is a fun action-adventure role-playing game (AARPG). It has a unique upgrade system that allows for more upgrades the more you explore an area. number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
er 30, 2013
												The best video game of all time, bar none; the sequels Invisible War (horrible game) and Human Revolution don't even come close. The game takes place in the year 2052 where the world has become a ghetto ravaged by war, terrorism, and disease. A new plague, known as the Gray Death, is spreading rapidly with no cure; only a vaccine known as Ambrosia can prevent infection, and only if you can keep taking it. Worst of all, production is extremely limited and most of it is rationed out to key government and utility workers. You play as UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) agent J.C. Denton, fresh out of the academy, on his first mission to reacquire a supply of Amrbosia that has been stolen by the terrorist group NSF (National Secessionist Forces). But it doesn't take long to figure out that something much more sinister is going on.Deus Ex features incorporates conspiracy theries (Illuminati, Trilateral Commission, Knights Templar, Majestic 12, etc) into a well-integrated cyberpunk storyline. It is the most cerebral game I've ever played, which focuses on the ideas of liberty and authority with very intelligent dialogue.The gameplay is incredible as well. Deus Ex is a FPS/RPG hybrid and the best I've seen in it's genre. You gain skill points that you can invest into different skills, such as Heavy Weaponry, Lockpicking, or Medicine. You also receive nano-augmentations throughout the game that can be toggled on or off at the expense of bioelectrical enegry, such as Quiet Movement or Invisibility.The only downside to this game, if you want to call it that, is that the graphics are outdated as the game came out in 2000. However, there are lots of mods that improve things like texture quality which make the game more visually pleasing. If you were a PC gamer around the time though (Half Life, Unreal, Tribes, etc) then it shouldn't phase in you the least bit.Play this game NOW. You're not a real PC gamer if you haven't. 10/10. Such fun. Much wow.

ber 11, 2015
												Well what can I say... This game needs a rework.It really was one of the best games of its time. Nowadays it lacks some of the simple things like changing music, more kinds of different npc looks, and overall a better.Nothing of that was bad, but after about 2 hours per level listening to the same music my head started to hurt.This game got some things even current games lack: - Full voice cast- Manymany items, not only useful ones.- Big world with many places you actually don't have to visit- A choice between good or bad (kill or sneak in this case)- A complex story.Too bad after 14 hours (with at least 6 hours to go) the game crashed at a certain point, no matter which savegame I used or which of the multiple ways I went. Would have loved to reach the end.

content:
5
												I've just beaten the game yesterday--first playthrough--and I've had a bit of time to reflect. I wish that I hadn't read a ton of reviews of people building this game up to be the best game ever. So if you haven't played yet, my advice is to go into it expecting that it'll be above average for its time (also assuming you're old enough to know what to expect from that era :P ). I think you'll enjoy it a lot more.I went in with VERY high expectations on the storyline becuase of all the reviews on here and wound up underwhelmed. Not only at the end of the game, but throughout as well. Just always wondering when it was gonna get really good. While the storyline was ok, I was never drawn in by it, and my reaction at some plot twists was more "huh...didn't expect that," than actual surprise.One main reason I never got pulled into the story was the absolutely horrible voice acting. They had 1 real person doing voices for like 15 different characters. With the lack of facial variation in the game, I was often confused if it was a new or old character I'd just met up with. The reason the individual voice acting was so bad is there was a complete lack of emotion in the voices. Impressively lacking I'd say. Like they grabbed people off the street. At first I thought it was about concerns for the size for the game fitting on disks back then, but the voices actually have acceptable bandwidth, just no change in pitch or volume. Finally in the last hours of the game ONE of the characters was emotive, raising their voice and changing the stress in the voice. Who knows, maybe it WAS a disk space thing, I'm not an expert.As you may have noticed, I do recommend the game. It's pretty good, and I hope I can relect on its backstory for when I play the later games (I know to skip Invisible War). But I think that there are a LOT of people who view it through star-struck eyes because they played it when it came out or it was the first game of this type that they played. Just as the original Halo has a special place in my heart, I realize I probably wouldn't think so highly of it if I started with the latest FPS games and THEN played Halo for the first time. But aside from Golden Eye, that was the first game of that sort I ever played--and right when it came out--so it left a huge impression on me.

content:
y 11, 2011
												Deus Ex is often claimed to be the best game in computer game history. Personally I agree but it's not without it's problems. Join me while I take a look at this critically praised title.The StoryDeus Ex begins in the docks of the island where the statue of liberty is located at. The island is under lockdown because of a terrorist attack by an organization called "NSF" that has managed to overtake the entire island. You are "JC" Denton, a nano augmented super agent working for the security agency UNATCO (United Nations Anti-Terrorist Coalition) and your task is to infiltrate the statue of liberty and capture the leader of the terrorist attack alive. You meet up with your brother: Paul Denton which gives you a weapon and the location of a contact that can help JC into the statue. JC is later tasked with working under the supervision of his machine augmented collegue Anna Navarre in several tasks related to attacks against the NSF. The story has no problem introducing new characters to you. All the major characters you meets are colorful and memorable but most of all they feel real.Level DesignWhen you exit the docks you come across patrolling terrorists pretty much instantly. How you prefer to go up to the tower of liberty is entirely up to you as there are a number of ways to do so. The level design in this very first level is optimized to be as open as possible with plenty of secrets so it makes newcomers confused as to where to start and how to approach the problem. If you search around you will find to be able to get the Sniper rifle and the Crossbow on the very first level of the game.The other levels in the game varies with open areas and enclosed areas but they're never entirely linear. They are more often than not full of branching paths but of course there are a few linear levels which JC has to venture though but even those can be progressed through in different ways, making for a truly varied experience. Almost all levels in the game allows for a subtle approach (or even several) but a direct assault approach is never out of the question either. However, the game rewards subtle approaches more than lethal ones which is apparent even in the first few levels of the game.There is however one level that I want to bring up, directly before you arrive in Hong Kong - where you need to rescue your helicopter from a hangar of some sort: While not being a bad level in it's own right - this level did not add anything to the game and felt entirely unnecessary to me.RPG ElementsJC Denton starts out with a couple of skill points which he invests in different skills. These are in several different areas ranging from very useful to merely a convenience. The developers are aware of the convenience skills and they cost a lot less than the more essential skills that you can invest in. So if you want to be able to be a great swimmer it will not cost as much as being a good hacker or a good shooter but it will still cost something. Even if you don't have any skills in the different areas you will still be able to do these tasks - albeit at a higher cost of the resources to carry out the tasks. For example you might come across a locked door. If you are untrained in lockpicking you will only be able to unlock 10 points (of a universal maximum of 100) from the lock per lockpick. As the tools of these trades are relatively difficult to acquire large numbers of and locked doors being plentiful this skill easily turns out to be one of the most useful ones. So if you're untrained you will merely have to be more selective in the doors you want to try and unlock. If you run out you can also sometimes just blow up the door with explosives but the explosives in this game is even more rare than lockpicks. Unlike lockpicks though - explosives mostly only need 1 charge to succeed.Deus Ex also features an "augmentation" system where you get to choose between different buffs and abilities JC will permanently be outfitted with during the game. JC can choose between being better at smashing peoples skulls in with melee weapons or lifting heavy boxes and crates. One allows JC to take people down in one hit and the other allows him to bring cover or trap people. You also get other kinds of abilities like being able to either be invisible to people or to cameras or being able to see details of your target (like health and weapons) or have night & heat vision. You always have to choose between two augmentations that works in similar ways but they also need to be upgraded and upgrading is something I think the game could have done without; because without the need to upgrade, augmentations could have been playing a larger role (especially in the early parts of the game) instead of being a bonus on top of JC's more useful Skills system.Combat and StealthBecause this is an RPG - Deus Ex's combat changes according to the skills JC acquires during the game. The game favors silent takedowns as the game isn't afraid of pitting you against several enemies at once, but in a way it is possible to try and engage the enemy with lethal weapons as well but perhaps not as rewarding. Eventually though JC pretty much needs to equip himself with some form of lethal weapons due to the increase of armored enemies during the later stages of the game. This oddly enough gives a sense of progression and a strange dynamic to the fights where you have to use the less lethal weapons against human grunts and the lethal ones against the tougher ones.There is one strange thing with Deus Ex's aiming system where you have to crouch in order to get maximum accuracy. It's mainly a way to allow players who doesn't have good fighting skills to still be able to defeat someone with a gun. The games has some other, more desirable options open for such players such as throwing grenades and using pepper spray.Of course sneaking is the greatest asset to JC and you don't have to skill up in order to be a great ninja in this game. In fact: JC starts as a pretty good ninja right from the start. As long as the player sticks to the shadows or behind the enemy he's not going to be able to see JC coming and be entirely in the mercy of the players whims.ConclusionDeus Ex does have it's problems, just like every single other game but somehow what Deus Ex tries really works. The story, despite it's weaknesses is ultimately very good. The pacing is brisk and you're never without any goals. The level design ranks as one of the best in games up to this point. And unlike so many other games from 2000 this game actually looks really good. Much of what isn't done very good or great is at least solid and the game has very few apparent weaknesses.Most games I play have quirks that makes the experience playing them somewhat worse by being central mechanics. Deus Ex's problems are very minor in comparison of it's qualities. The augmentation system that I mentioned earlier is after all "a bonus" since JC's power really comes from his skills system. That's why I believe Deus Ex is as great as gaming has ever gotten and deserve a 6 out of 6.

In fact: JC starts as a pretty good ninja right from the start. As long as the player sticks to the shadows or behind the enemy he's not going to be able to see JC coming and be entirely in the mercy of the players whims.ConclusionDeus Ex does have it's problems, just like every single other game but somehow what Deus Ex tries really works. The story, despite it's weaknesses is ultimately very good. The pacing is brisk and you're never without any goals. The level design ranks as one of the best in games up to this point. And unlike so many other games from 2000 this game actually looks really good. Much of what isn't done very good or great is at least solid and the game has very few apparent weaknesses.Most games I play have quirks that makes the experience playing them somewhat worse by being central mechanics. Deus Ex's problems are very minor in comparison of it's qualities. The augmentation system that I mentioned earlier is after all "a bonus" since JC's power really comes from his skills system. That's why I believe Deus Ex is as great as gaming has ever gotten and deserve a 6 out of 6.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
7, 2013
												A true gem, even by modern-day standards, Deus Ex took me a while to get in to. It wasn't until a few missions/hours in that I was really hooked, but as the story became more understandable and the levels more varied (and there are a lot), I got to look past the dated graphics and A.I., and found a really deep, enthralling title with lots of rewarding exploration and true varied playstyles: you can complete any level how you want and there are a number of ways to do it. I would recommend Deus Ex to any fan of shooters, as it can fit almost all shooter playstyles: run and gun, stealth and snipe, superhuman abilities, melee, etc. The story and voice acting is great, and a long, content-filled adventure of conspiracy and tension. Great endings. 9/10

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
30, 2014
 Introduction Deus Ex is a first-person shooter published and developed by Ion Storm Houston in June 26, 2000. Directed by Warren Spector, Deus Ex is about one man’s destiny of becoming the God in the Machine to make a truly fair autonomous world government that appeals to the minds of the living – though this is only the first of many choices to take.Deus Ex is an incredibly influential game of it's time known for level design and scripting which has been designed towards various players actions that a player may take to complete an objective, a breakthrough in “emergent” gameplay and through experimentation secret dialogues and other rewards unlock through the exploration and reward.  Deus Ex’s setting is that of a futuristic cyberpunk world shrouded in ambiguity and fear as a nanite-virus known as the Grey Death spreads across the American continent and rural areas committing to the genocide of millions of people! The working classes, now cower in constant fear and terror of their government’s policies. It’s dark ambience and semi-realistic representation of 21st century world in turmoil coupled with the scale of its maps, intelligent design and humor help deliver an intense, conspiracy-themed world with high re-playability. Gameplay Deus Ex is a hybrid of First Person Shooter and Role Playing elements. Though semi-linear, there is many quests to do in the game which offers a challenge and reward of skill points or weapons/upgrades. There is a total of 10 skills in the game; Computer, Rifle, Low-Tech, Pistol, Heavy, Environmental Training, Swimming, Medicine, Electronics and Lockpicking.  These Skill upgrades improve Denton's ability to hack, swim (rarely used), shoot certain types of weapons without movement or accuracy penalties, jump higher, regenerate health, deactivate security restrictions such as a locked door to an armory or shop, gain access to robots interfaces and drones.4 difficulties are Easy, Medium, Hard and Realistic, all 3 increase NPC health and damage dealt but Realistic Realistic deals heavy damage on different body parts for both parties depending on what weapon is used to kill a target. Recommendations Lore-heavy with elements of interwoven themes concerning the socioeconomical abuse of a nation, the results of a corruptive government and the dangers of indiscriminate survillence giving the game a great sense of scale, depth, and mystery compared to games of its time.Modification friendly. Deus Ex uses Unreal engine to run so many SDK tools can be used to create new content. My recommended ones would be Deus Ex GMDX, Revision, Shifter and the tons at MODDB; http://www.moddb.com/games/deus-ex/mods Criticisms; Minor Requires Kentie’s Direct3D 10 renderer for extended options and playability.Deus Ex is very clunky gameplay wise with a considerable amount of skill bloat. To briefly explain this, a lot of augmentations overlap the Skills in the game such as Swimming and Environmental Training which are notorious for being the least useful skills to train in the game because they can be replaced with items or biological modification that do the same thing and better.Graphically poor, even for it’s time. Designs of certain weaposn are bland and nonsensical (such as the Stealth Pistol being a bullpup pistol) Animations are varied but stilted and wooden looking.Deus Ex's level design can be very confusing and maze-like at the end-game. The best thing to do is  is to explore and find new things. Gunplay The gunplay has a great selection of combat tools and different ammunition but is extremely clunky and spread is random until you gain the Targetting augmentation or use Gun Modifications to upgrade Accuracy of the selected weapon. You can use everything from Crowbars, Tasers to Rocket Launchers and Turrets (with the help of a Computer Skill) to take down enemies or you can use stealth and toss a throwing knife into the throat of a weary enemy. The game takes heavy considerations for what body parts are hit - for example, hitting a crowbar at the base of the spine will instantly knock or kill a target or a gunshot of a large rifle to the torso or head will terminate their life and in opposing manner you as well on Realistic Difficulty.  Music Deus Ex music was composed by Alexander Brandon, who is known for focusing heavily upon electronic and classical hybrids similar to Vangelis’ works. It is dynamic, peppy and very beat heavy - influenced in a unique way by the players actions. Assaulting enemies and friendlies will cause the music to be suddenly rough, choatic classic electronica hybrid ochestra (yes, it is THAT good) to a calm, placid ambient drone that heals the ears when visiting the bustling cities when walking around or sneaking. You should have a listen to Alexander Brandon's works as they are very sublime for their time. Graphics The Unreal 1 engine was updated in Deus Ex to allow for coloured lightmaps, textured shading, mipmapping, skeletal animation (to include more advanced animations). Though Deus Ex paled in graphics in comparison to other games, the world is still believable and large for it's time. Due to the expandability, the source code and SDK's packaged with Deus Ex, this produced many modifications from graphical, gameplay and to minor changes such as changes to HUD. Mechanics Deus Ex uses a 'Skill Point' design to allocated a fixed price of skill points which are earned by doing quests, use of dialogue, clever exploration or by experimenting with certain actions in the game's environment.Deus Ex awards exploration, inquistiveness and theres tons of hidden content, including story, items, mini-quests and lets you play as if it were an open-world and it gets better from there! Many, many guns to choose from, many ways to play stealthy or violently.Deus Ex makes much use of emergent gameplay, meaning your actions can take serious consequences and changes to rewards and storyline. The very first level can be played in many different ways - some that you would think the developer would miss! Storyline The introduction begins with two mysterious figures amongst a large statue of a hand palming the globe, explaining their plans for a new augmentation project and the virus known as Grey Death.Meanwhile… J.C Denton, a rookie officer at UNATCO is briefed to take action and arrest an NSF commander by his brother Paul Denton. UNATCO is an anti-terrorist organisation founded after the Statue of Liberty was blown up by Northwest/Nationalist Secessionist Forces, a “terrorist” group. J.C Denton is sent with his brother Paul Denton to find the source of the deadly plague that haunts American civilizations with an atmosphere of death and secret control. The player as JC finds out more and more about the sinister plague and the lack of Ambrosia, its cure. This leads you, the player (and by extension JC) into finding out much more than what meets the eye as you find leads all round the world leading you to the ultimate conspiracy.

content:
er 16, 2016
												Is DEUS EX the greatest game ever?It might be. Seldom, if ever, has a game blended so well elements of first person shooters, stealth, assassin and puzzle games, all into an RPG with great combat, minigames, and a self-driven narrative. While it is stylistically dated--shades of the MATRIX show throughout--the story is a rich one, and the game has remarkable replay value. Rarely is it ever the same game twice. Play it now, play it again, and live the perfect Cyberpunk RPG. 15 years after it hit shelves, it's still a treasure for gamers everywhere.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 25, 2016
												Holy christ, I just saw this game on sale for one dollar and seventy-four cents. $1.74. Get it. This game is an absolute gem and a legend within the cyberpunk genre. An early rpg/fps entry that oozes nostalgia and exudes genius. I'm not the best at reviewing games, but there are those hidden amongst Steam that I feel are too amazing not to promote... this is one of them.You play as agent JC Denton, a shiny new nano-augmented agent (successor to mechanically-augmented agents) in a counter-terrorist organization dubbed UNATCO. The secretive politicking and social banter you'll be exposed to can be overheard from enemies mid-conversation, read through security terminals throughout the gameworld, deluged via e-mails sent to your character (as well as other non-player characters, provided you can gain access to their accounts...) will influence how you want to play your character. Do you blindly obey the higher-ups in your organization, or lean toward the ideals of UNATCO's enemy--a 'terrorist' organization calling themselves the NSF.Between the conspiracy theories, feeding homeless kids for intel, jumping on rats, getting turnt on zyme, breaking into storage rooms for bags of soy nuts... there's intelligent humor and timeless music to help you immerse yourself in Ion Storm's take on a futuristic dystopian United States of America.OH AND NOT TO MENTION: REVISION. It's a breathtaking graphical overhaul of the game, provided as a free DLC through Steam. Deus Ex is given a facelift for the 21st century (which goes deeper than mere graphics, mind you) and you're also given the option to play the game with two of it's most famous mods-Biomod and Shifter.Again, I'm no good at reviewing but by all that is holy, you need to pick up this classic masterpiece in PC gaming. $1.74, I still can't believe it!!!Welcome to the coalition, JC.

												I'm not going to present the game and what it is about since you can easily read that anywhere else. Everyone knows Deus Ex. I don't expect this title to have any apeal to the early generations of gamer, but this game was praised by many for good reasons. Despite its old unreal engine, blocky designs and poor combat IA, the game shines through its brillant story telling, plot setting, lore, ambiance and RPG elements in a FPS. It's the achievement of people who worked on System Shock and Thief (also very inovative for their time) and you can feel they kept their personal touch in future titles like the Bioshock franchise and the latest Deus Ex titles.Heck, it even earned a meme of its own. "Deus Ex: Everytime you mention it, someone will reinstall it." .... well, back when memes were untaged and cool.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
er 26, 2016
												“Without leaps of imagination or dreaming, we lose the excitement of possibilities.” (Gloria Steinem)Nowadays, most games are well-polished updates of old games: Beautiful or retro graphics, good stories, new environments, well-rounded gameplay - but without new ideas, without invention, without creating anything of their own.Deus Ex was different.Its developers created something never seen before, something fresh, giving players a degree of freedom and choice in accomplishing their objectives that was unprecedented. They got the graphics, sound, story, and other elements on a par with or better than others at the time, but they did more than just that. The game did not fit into an existing genre, it defined its own, took that evolutionary leap into the unknown that has become so rare in the industry. By now, many other games have followed in its path. But Deus Ex was a groundbreaking title, it was the first of its kind. +1 for taking that leap:  11/10

content:
ber 29, 2016
												Deus Ex is showing its years, particularly in the graphics department, and I had an issue with the high-def mod I tried, in which everything else was fine but having water anywhere onscreen would slow everything to a crawl. But I'd still recommend the game. I already have three different character builds going, so I can try three different skill builds without knowing yet what I might need or not need later on in the game: a hacker, a sharpshooter, and a Thief-style lock-picking, head-bonking, hug-that-shadow-like-it's-his-girlfriend version. I'm pretty sure I'll be way past three before I'm done. I like the comments NPCs make, both idly and about some of the actions I take in the game. It's fun fluff. Also fun is that there are multiple ways to proceed to goals, and multiple ways to deal with trouble encountered in getting there. I've gone at the game stealth-knockout style, or guns blazing, or avoiding combat (or sneaky head-bonking) as much as possible, and all three ways were fun. There's occasionally things I wish I could try to do and can't-- like offer an NPC asking for thing A if thing B would be an acceptable alternative-- but there always will be.Speaking of that, let's talk nitpicks: I'm not a fan of the crouchwalking-to-sneak part, the sneaking part is fun, but the crouching feels awkward. The grid-style "realistic space usage" inventory (necessitating inventory-fussing to make a space of the right shape for an object I want to pick up) is as annoying as it always is, although not quite enough so to make me mod it out. I'm not crazy about the hack-o-meter countdown either. I was hoping there'd be some way for Denton to download the documents for a more convenient read, given that this takes place in a world in which cybernetics and nano-augmentation exist, but if there is one I haven't noticed. They don't seem to be showing up anywhere in the ingame logs the way conversations do, which seems a bit backwards to me.Well, as far as that last one goes, it is a game that was made before USB or wireless goodness existed... So, given that augs are a thing in Deus Ex and those things probably should be too, and that I was getting really annoyed by this nitpicky detail, I went to a game wiki for the text of documents I discovered while using the Hack skill. I now read them that way as I find them ingame, waiting until a point when "Denton" reasonably could stop and check out what he'd found, and it's much more fun now.Minor irritants aside, I'm having a lot of fun with Deus Ex, another title I didn't get to enjoy when it was released. Definitely better late than never.
